title: Prusa i3 MK3 Extruder Housing Extra Fan Adapter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
From viewing a few videos, I don't think there is enough space for this fan and adapter to fit when the X-axis carriage slides all the way to the left to home itself.

Updated 1/7/18 5:08 pm EST
Redesigned the revolved loft to better fit the fans housing and flow area.
It comes in UPSIDE DOWN in Simplified3D. Place the fan mounting face side on the build plate. PLA is probably good as temprature should not be high in this area.

This is an untested fan adapter for a 25mm x 25mm cooling fan to mount onto the MK3 upper extruder access hole. I think this will fit but it has never been printed by me yet to test. The angled adapter can use #2 machine screw or a 2mm screw to attach it to the extruder housing. You will need to drill smaller holes into the extruder plastic housing for the attachment screws. You will want to buy a 25mm x 25mm cooling fan that operates on 12 volts for easier installation and one that is near or less that 20db of noise. I would temporarily attach it to test before drilling into the extruder housing. A dust infiltration filter could be designed and attached onto the fan to keep any dust from blowing into the extruder feed gears and nozzle feed area if needed.

The reason for this extra fan is to possibly remove any heat flowing up into the filament sensor area.

Wish you luck! Enjoy

This is really fast project you can do. This plane designed to fly! Almost no cost required. Fave fun!

Materials:
1x straw with 5mm diameter and a length between 7-8 inches or 18-21 cm;
1x Nut with 5mm inner diameter (N10);
3x or more plane suport frame (STL file);
1x A4 cardboard with ~0.6mm thickness;

First you need to put plane's supports on straw. Then print, cut and put the wings on the frame. You can put duck tape or super glue on wings to make sure they do not came off with crashes. Finally put the nut on plane's nose, this will a balance your plane. Make sure the nut is secure. You will need to find the balance of your plane between the nut and the wings to plane fly.

Comment if you make it and what was your difficulty. Also follow me on Instagram for more projects @screw._it

title: BB8 - Star Wars RC Droid
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is an easy to build Disney Star Wars BB8 inspired robot. It's controlled by an Arduino UNO over a bluetooth connection from your smartphone.

Part one in our series covers the majority of the electrical assembly, and the creation of his main body.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qFbfLk-jUd4
Here us the second part available now: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=o28ejTRMKo0

List of items used in this project and where to find them:

■ Styrofoam Ball: http://amzn.to/2Drccpn
■ Arduino Uno:http://amzn.to/2xbXNK4
■ Motor shield: http://amzn.to/2gQUkL0
■ HM10 Bluetooth model: http://amzn.to/2kW8BYs
■ Motor and wheel: http://amzn.to/2mQGYxl
■ Magnets: http://amzn.to/2D6kZte
■ Battery: http://amzn.to/2my0df4
■ Battery Holder (eBay): https://tinyurl.com/y9hwbhf2
■ Hycote White Primer: http://amzn.to/2FA0mGS
■ Metallic Sharpies: http://amzn.to/2GFXJoo
■ Set of Sharpies: http://amzn.to/2EvauRO

SUBSCRIBE:
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC3jc4X-kEq-dEDYhQ8QoYnQ?sub_confirmation=1

During the creation of part two I realised I would need a hot wire cutter to cut the styrofoam in half. (The bread knife attempt made A LOT of mess and I got in trouble with the other half). Here you can find instructions on how to build your own battery powered one:
https://youtu.be/l8lAdbMGkgU

INSTAGRAM: https://www.instagram.com/diy_machines/?hl=en
FACEBOOK:https://www.facebook.com/diymachines/?ref=aymt_homepage_panel
PATREON: https://www.patreon.com/diymachines

Disclaimer:
This video is shared for demonstration purposes only.
BB8 is a Disney Star Wars created character. I make no claim to its design, merchandise or anything like that. This is fan art for the community.

A separate power source in the head could also allow me to install a few other modules.  Maybe instead of magnets in the head, a steel disk (or even an array of magnets, or magnetize the disk) so that I can turn the head around....
comments.author: DIY_Machines

comments.text:
That's something that I wanted to do, but I found that at the scale required to make a unit relatively easy to 3D print (so that as many people could make on as possible) I did not have the space. As the head gets heavier you require more magnetism to hold it in place. As the magnets get stronger you need better rollers or ball bearings to allow it move over the ball with little resistance. What's offered here is the sweet spot I settled on between features, cost and skill requirements.
Go for it though, it's certainly possible! Share a video if you get it working.

title: Customizable roller adapter for Kossel Mini with 2020 extrusion

description.text:
I noticed one of my carriage wheels is wiggling, so I ordered new rollers and those, of course, happen to be of different size. The designs available are not exactly non-customizable, but reading through .scad and figuring out how to adjust all the hardcoded values is not something a developer can tolerate. Especially if one may expect having to do that again in the future. So based on the existing designs I've made one that is customizable based on parameters that are meaningful.

The prebuilt .stl file is for roller 11mm thick with effective diameter of 22mm (the actual roller diameter is about 24mm) and M5 screws. It has both the longer and 20x20 mount options because I'm going to redo the carriage as well and not yet sure what mount option I will pick.

Customizer allows adjustment for the inner and effective diameter and thickness, .scad has more customization possibilities.

title: Yet Another KX2 "VFO A" Tuning Knob

description.text:
A common complaint about the KX2 radio is that its VFO A tuning knob is on the smallish side. (Of course the entire radio is small, so it is expected.) Several Thingiverse contributors have offered designs to overcome this short-coming of a truly outstanding QRP rig. Unfortunately, and in just my opinion, most of these designs fall short in 1 of these 4 areas:

  • I couldn't get them to fit my VFO's shaft, being either too large or too small. Without the CAD file, it took lots of tweaking in my slicer to get a good fit.
  • They don't match the aesthetic of the other knobs on the radio
  • The design was hard to print, requiring scaffolding, etc.
  • Didn't have a tactile feel that I liked.

So here is my design; attempting to make the best looking KX2 knob that I could. It uses openSCAD, and the source is included. This allows you to customize it yourself using openSCAD on your computer, or use the Thingiverse Customizer.

I've also included a small test part that allows you to quickly determine whether the knob will fit on your radio without taking the time to print the entire knob. Differences in printers, plastic, slicers, extrusion settings, etc. make it impossible for a "one size fits all" setting for the "ShaftDiameter" variable. Whether you print the actual knob or the test shaft is determined by the "Knob_or_Test" variable at the top of the openSCAD file.

You can find this knob for sale at https://stores.ebay.com/N0WL-Radio if you don't have the means or desire to print your own.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

your choice, but 100% give a heavier solid feel to the knob

Notes:

Differences in 3D printers, plastics, slicers, extrusion settings, temperature, etc. can cause the fit of the shaft to vary. The shaft test file is include to test the fit before you take the time to print the entire knob. But, even so, there may be slight variations in size between the test print and the final knob.

You can modify the value of the ShaftDiameter variable in the Customizer or in openSCAD. Or you can tweak the size of the knob a few percent in your slicer.

I use:

  • Prusa I3 MK2S
  • Simplify3D
  • Inland PLA

Simplify3D lays the final top layers down in a straight line at a 45 degree angle to the bed. If you rotate the knob -45 degrees in Simplify3D, it sets the final layer lines in the same direction as the finger divot. This gives the best look in my humble opinion. Try your slicer options and see what looks best to you. Simplify3D's "Concentric" External Fill Patter (on the Infill Advanced Process Settings page) gives a great look to the top surface too!
Note: optionally, a light coat of clear dull-coat paint will take away the sheen on the knob to better match the look of the radio's other knobs

title: Taz 3-5 Power Supply Cover for MW SE-450-24 (or equiv.)

description.text:
This is a two piece cover for a Mean Well SE-450-24 replacement power supply for Taz 3-5.
It will also fit similar power supplies with the same pattern of M3 mounting screws on the side. The 4 holes on the sides are not equidistant from the edges, so check you dimension to match an MW SE-450-24.
This cover allows the power supply to be mounted on the side of a Taz 4 (Taz 3-5 and others).
I used .28mm layers and PLA. Some support it the vertical cutouts will insure parts will fit.
I cut the DC cable to 33" (840mm) plus 6" (150mm) for connection inside the cover.
Use a tie wrap inside and outside of the cover piece to restrain the DC cable!
The small inner cover is mounted using three M3 screws. I recommend using an M3 tap, although you could get by using a screw. Take care not to overtighten and strip out the hole. If you strip it out, use an M3 nut on the inside or fill the hole and start over.
I split the cover into two pieces to make it easier to print and to yield a better print job.
You will need 4 M4 x 10-12mm screws and washers to mount on the power supply, and 3 M3 x 10-12mm to install the small cover piece into the the main cover part.
The cables, DC and AC are clamped to the spare M3 holes on the rear side of the power supply.
The adapter mount for attaching the power supply to the side of the frame is here:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2741775

description.text:
This is a platform for the Polymaker Polysher that supports 1/8inch and 1/4 inch pins so that you can smooth multi-part pieces without worrying about ruining the surface of the part you are polishing. Put one end of the pin in the piece you've designed and the other end in the platform, this will keep the part upright during the smoothing process so that the surface isn't damaged.

This model has a 0.2mm print tolerance built in. What this means is that each hole is 0.4mm larger than it needs to be to account for printer shenanigans.

title: FDM printed SLA-Printer by TOS
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Update 19.02.2018:
While testing, it turned out that I underestimated the criticality of a good VAT design. While I liked the simplicity of the predecessing VAT design a lot, it turned out that it just wasn't able to maintain the tension of the foil over a longer period.
Today I uploaded a enhanced VAT design, consisting of 3 seperate 3D printed parts.
Build instructions for the new VAT can be found on YouTube:
https://youtu.be/L0omLMDEv60

Update 03.02.2018:
Uploaded some build instructions for the printer body and z-axis to YouTube...
https://youtu.be/DbIEzbua1AI

Update 01.02.2018:
Uploaded "tosla_31_uvdifusor.stl". Must be printed in transparent material and need to be installed inside the uv-reflector.

Update 29.01.2018:
First successful test today. Here is some video footage:
https://youtu.be/10tiZy_Tpp8

Update 26.01.2018:

  • updated zslider to "tosla_31_zslider.stl"
    (only "cosmetics" and less material, no functional change; older version can still be used)

Update 20.01.2018:
this is a major update that reflects first test results and fixes a lot of issues:

  • changed build plate to aluminium with hole-pattern to reduce suction effect, therefore 3D-printed part consists only of the handle, aluminium plate must be cutted, drilled separately.
  • shortened z-gantry to reduce leverage effect of forces to the z-axis.
  • moved z-stepper motor and smooth rods closer to vat, so z-gantry can be more shortened (see above)
  • used space that become availble by moving z-stepper motor to the front to add two additional aluminium bars (15x15 mm) to the back of the printer. This will add a lot of stability to the z-axis.
  • redesigned the VAT completely as it turned out that it was way to over-engineered in the first place
  • re-positioned z-endstops to fit in available spaces after re-positioning all the other stuff

...therefore the following 3D-printed parts have been updated to reflect all those changes:

  • updated the vat base to "tosla_28_vat.stl" (less parts/material, better assambly of foil)
  • updated the build plate to "tosla_29_zplate.stl"
  • updated the z-slider to "tosla_29_zslider.stl"
  • updated the z-top to "tosla_29_ztop.stl"
  • updated the z-shaft to "tosla_29_zshaft.stl"
  • updated the body-core to "tosla_29_bodycore.stl"

Update 14.01.2018:

  • updated the vat base to "tosla_26_vatbase.stl" to fix a minor issue.
  • updated the vat basin to "tosla_26_vatbasin.stl" to fix a minor issue.

Update 09.01.2018:

  • added missing uv-reflector-frame "tosla_25_uvreflector.stl"
  • updated the vat base to "tosla_25_vatbase.stl" to fix a minor issue.
  • updated the vat basin to "tosla_25_vatbasin.stl" to fix a minor issue.

Just a pre-release of the STL's for my FDM-printed SLA printer.
It's still work in progress, therefore no final/complete BOM and/or instructions for the moment.

There is a first video on YouTube that explains the z-gantry design:
https://youtu.be/xuOsPoC8g8Q

BOM (work in progress):

  • Raspberry Pi Modell 3
  • 5.5 inch lcd display 2560x1440,
  • HDMI-MIPI driver pcb compatible with 5.5 inch display
  • glass protector for 5.5 inch dispaly
  • DC converter 9a 4-40 V to 1,2-34 V, adjustable constant current (65x48x24mm)
  • FEP film (150 x 200 mm, 0.025 mm thick)
  • 4x 10 watt power UV-LED, 405nm wavelength
  • 2x microswitch 3pin NO/NC/C, 1a 125 VAC (12,8x5.8x10mm)
  • 12v 5a external power supply (barrel connector 2.1 ID, 5.5 OD)
  • DRV8825 stepper driver (or pin compatible)
  • Nema 17 stepper motor
  • 130 x 56 x 20 mm aluminium heatsink
  • 40 x 40 x 10 mm 12v fan
  • flat HDMI cable with 90 degree type A connector 200 mm flat ribbon cable
  • thermal adhesive tape (as used for heatsink assamblies)
  • 1602 Serial LCD module with I2C interface
  • 5mm LED
  • voltage regulator pcb MP1584EN
  • mosfet IRFZ44N
  • some resistores (1x 100 Ohm, 4x 10k, 1x 100k)
  • capacitor 50v 100µF
  • some pinhead connectors (1x 2x20 female, 8x 1x2 male, 2x 1x4 male, 4x 1x3 male, 2x 1x8 male)
  • 2x screw terminal (2pins, 5.08mm pitch)
  • hole matrix board 70 x 50 mm, double sided, 2.54 mm pitch/ 0.1 inch pitch
  • hole matrix board 20 x 34 mm, double sided, 2.54 mm pitch/ 0.1 inch pitch
  • circular power switch, 19mm diameter, 250 VDC 6 Ampere
  • female barrel power connector (2.1 ID, 5.5 OD)
  • tactile switch 6x6x4,3, 4pin
  • a bunch of m3 10mm screws
  • 2x LM8LUU linear bearings
  • 2x aluminium pipes 8mm OD

(...to be continued)

There will be some update with more details later.

Regards, TOS

comments.text:
Just go on the following download side of nanodlp. There is an easy step by step installation instruction.
https://www.nanodlp.com/download/
Basically, you download a complete SD-card image file that contains some kind of linux-os with nanodlp already installed on top of it.
The only thing thats really a little bit tricky, is the linux setup for the hdmi-display. But this is very well explained here:
(just scroll down to the chapter "Configure Raspberry PI3 HDMI to support 1440×2560 pixel resolution" ignore the rest)
https://3dprinterwiki.info/d7/d7-nanodlp-settings-2/
The rest of the configuration is done via the nanodlp user interface: connect the raspberry pi to your LAN-router via ethernet cable, check the router to find out the assigned TCP/IP-adress of the raspberry by, use some other PC/ Notebook that is attached to your LAN, open a browser and type the TCP/IP-adress into the address line. the nanodlp UI should show up in the browser.

comments.text:
I am looking at this LCD on aliexpress https://goo.gl/77Ed2r
and it has a backlit and non-backlit version,
which of the version should we use?
comments.author: sameers

comments.text:
you have to remove the backlit anyway, so by choosing the option without backlit, it save you a couple of bugs, the time and effort to remove it yourself and not to forget the risk of destroying the display while removing the backlit yourself.
Just be aware, that once the backlit is removed the rest of the display gets extremely fragile and should become immediatly supported with something like this:
https://de.aliexpress.com/item/MARKE-NEUE-DLP-SLA-3d-drucker-KLD-1260-3D-drucker-bildschirm-glasschutz-display-schutzfolie/32846486906.html?spm=a2g0x.search0104.3.15.44dd6457nxJTGV&ws_ab_test=searchweb0_0%2Csearchweb201602_4_10320_10152_10321_10065_10151_10344_10068_10342_10547_10343_10322_10340_10341_10548_10193_10194_10084_10083_10618_10304_10307_10302_5711211_10180_10313_10059_10184_10534_100031_10319_10103_10627_10626_10624_10623_10622_10186_10621_5722412_10620_5711311%2Csearchweb201603_2%2CppcSwitch_5&algo_expid=fa0e38bc-b637-4822-bd65-4405ea66355a-2&algo_pvid=fa0e38bc-b637-4822-bd65-4405ea66355a&transAbTest=ae803_3&priceBeautifyAB=0
Ther is a great video on youtube that explains how the backlit has to be removed and how that protective glass needs to be applied. Also: that kind of protective glass comes already with the right type of adhasive prepared. Its basically like an selfadhasive tape: just peel of the protective sheet and carefully apply it to the display (prevent air bubbles and dust):
https://youtu.be/lARBUQOkfuM
comments.author: sameers

comments.text:
Couple more questions -
what are you using as mirrors in the uv reflector? I cannot see them in BOM and in video i don't understand that word (goole provides subtitles as "couple of mirror retards" :P )
How big would be a difference in using 0.1mm FEP film insted of 0.025mm? i cannot find any reasonable source at this thickess..
Aluminium plate on building block is around 5mm thick?
comments.author: slimag

comments.text:
google for "PET mirror tiles" or go on amazon:
https://www.amazon.com/Reflective-Stickers-Self-adhesive-Decorations-16PCS15x15cm/dp/B076WT3K7N/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1519843825&sr=8-1&keywords=pet+mirror+tiles
I testet them: they are highly reflective also to uv-light spectrum, they are lightweight, stiff enough to maintain shape, flexible enough to get bent, can be cutted with scissors and relatively unexpensive.
I can't give a precise answer on the FEP film, as I actually did more testing with PP foil and also like to test other material. The right thickness depends somehow on how flexing the material is and the geometry of the VAT. So for me it's currently about "trial and error" on that topic.
The aluminium plate is 5mm thick. the holes for prevent suction have a diameter of 3mm and best done with a press drill. there are two additional holes with 2.5mm where afterwards a M3 thread has been cut into (for screwing the handle onto it). Maybe the handle can alternatively glued to the aluminium plate, but I went with the screws and didn't try that.

comments.text: Stupid question: I dont think this will be less expensive than a D7. So whats the point? Same Resolution, same built volume (expect z), but lots of work and time.
comments.author: Semme

comments.text: Depends a lot on suppliers and prices. I estimated material costs roughly about 250-260 € (assumed that small stuff like wires, connectors, screws are already on hands). D7 with shipping is still a higher price tag. Besides of that, D7 has no 'stand alone' capabilitiy: requires a connected PC that can handle an additional hdmi connected display and more or less occupies that PC during print (thats not the case with the raspberry pi/nandodlp concept of this printer). But I did it basically for fun and learning experience, not to save money.

So all of you out there that own a Gan Air SM know how frustrating it is when you are opening your GES container to swap springs or tension your cube. The nuts fly everywhere or they fall into the slot where the tensioning tool goes into and you cant get them out. I have designed a container to store all the GES Springs, including the ones that are already in the cube, and hold both of your tensioning tools. I made an extra slot for a 7th blue nut if you have one for some reason. I haven't 3D printed this yet and don't know if it works. If you want to print this, go ahead. If you do print this, make sure to tell me how it printed and how it works.

title: Stability Base and Clip for Bosch Hand Drill Model: PS31

description.text:
I needed a small drill to travel with and this was the only one they had at Lowes. It's actually a really powerful drill and much more comfortable to drag around all day however it can't balance on the battery pack with a bit in the chuck and there is no belt clip. I designed this base adapter for the small battery packs using Fusion 360.

Drill Model: Bosch PS31
Product Page:
https://www.boschtools.com/us/en/boschtools-ocs/cordless-drills-ps31-2a-34760-p/

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.03mm

Infill:

.45

Notes:

Printed in ABS 1.75mm.

Using Dr. Lex Creator Pro settings: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2367215

  • Print Settings: ABS-MediumStrong ( Supports enabled .01 contact distance)
  • Filament Settings: ABS-FlashForge-WHT
  • Printer Settings: Single Material R

Software

CAD: Fusion 360 https://www.autodesk.com/products/fusion-360/overview
Slicer: Slic3r Slicer http://slic3r.org/
Post: GPX gcode to x3g conversion https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:81425

Attaching to the battery pack:

The battery pack is attached to a plastic outer shell with about 3mm between the battery and the shell. I decided to use 4-40 screws to hold it on given the drill will be hanging from this clip and I didn't trust tape. If you don't plan to use the belt clip or you aren't comfortable drilling the holes I recommend using tape or glue. ( If not done right the battery could be ruined or explode)
Front Screw: 4-40 X 3/4"
Rear Screw: 4-40 X 1/4"

Add some PTFE tube to the top and bottom parts to ensure the filament does not wear through the item, you only need a small length and should just push in. Mount it so the cap faces down and add some course foam that you poke a hole down the middle of. Ersatz für einen Schwimmer im Tank. Da ein Schwimmer keinen Auftrieb mehr hatte, musste nun endlich mal Ersatz geschaffen werden.Zum Glück war es nur der für die "Doppeltasse".
Ich hatte damals Styropor als auftriebsmittel benutzt, aber so wirklich funktioniert hat es nicht.
warum auch immer. Wasser kann ja eigentlich nur von unten eindringen und die Luft eigentlich nicht entweichen.

Jedenfalls habe ich jetzt einen Ersatzschwimmer konstruiert. Die Schwierigkeit dabei ist es einen Magnet an die Front, im inneren des Modells, zu kleben.
Somit kann der Magnet auch nicht wie beim Original rosten.

Dazu muss eine Pause bei ca. 7mm im Slicer generiert werden.
Mein erster Druck ist mit Infill gedruckt und Funktioniert. jedoch ist es vermutlich einfacher ohne Infill zu drucken und dafür die Deckschichten oben zu erhöhen. Damit der Schwimmkörper auch wirklich dicht wird.
Denn mit Infill lässt sich der Magnet nur schwierig positionieren.

Anmerkung: Der Original Schwimmer ist aus PP.

title: Front derailler cable guide for Cannondale Chase

description.text:
After having used my Cannondale Chase for many years for dirt jump activities, I wanted to convert it back into a normal mountain bike for my 10 years old son. The cable guide for the front derailleur was missing... so I've printed a new one...
The diameter of the cable guide is the same as the bottom bracket, but due to the uneven welding it doesn't fit perfectly to the weld and the bottom bracket. This is why you will have to heat the printed cable guide wit a hair dryer then you'll have to press on the cable guide in the right position and it will perfectly fit to the uneven shape on your frame.

All the info you need should be in this description. If you have any further questions please check the comments section.

People have been sending tips! This is great considering that creating these designs and testing/adjusting from feedback takes time and effort. If you like the Proteus Keyholder consider sending a tip through the Tip Designer button on my profile page: https://www.thingiverse.com/ProteanMan/about

This works like a swiss army knife with your keys folding into the holder. Each holder is designed to have an equal number of keys at each end. The center bolt keeps the keys from crossing onto each other. You can fit as many keys as you want on this, just have to get a long enough bolt.

NEW
Old fashioned key size. This is a requested edition and has been sized to fit a general purpose old fashioned key (see image). You will need spacers for this one - look in the files. This size is larger than the standard key size with a length of 112mm and a width of 33mm.

Choices

  • 3mm Bolts
  • 2mm Bolts
  • Large Key Ring
  • Small Key Ring

Materials Needed

  • PETG, HTPLA, or ABS are preferred. Anything stronger works too. PLA may be too weak for regular use.
  • 3x bolts
  • 3x nuts or knurls
    (If you don't know what a knurl is then look at the pictures. You can buy them in packages online. Check image for knurl dimensions needed)

Bolt Sizes
Both 3mm and 2mm bolts can be found by measuring the thickness of the keys you want to put into the key holder + 6mm.
example: 6 keys with 3 at each end (pictures). 3 keys total width is 10mm + 6mm for keyholder body insets = 16mm bolt length.

Knurl Sizes
There is a picture with the suggested dimensions of the Knurls. 3mm and 2mm knurls have varying dimensions based on manufacturer. They won't work unless you have the proper dimensions to grip the holes. Knurls can be easily put in with a large set of plyers/clamp/hammer. They need to be pushed into place so that the edges cut and grip the hole. I use these for almost everything since they are easier and more reliable than standard nuts.

Key Spacers
There are two sizes of spacers. You can use a washer if you want, but plastic spacers may be better for the keys.
Standard Key Spacers come in 1mm and 1.5mm thickness
Old Fashioned Style Key Spacers come in 1mm and 2mm thickness. You can make your own easily through www.tinkercad.com if you don't have a CAD program.

Note: I personally don't use spacers since I like how the keys grip each other and stay together in my pocket. It's all personal preference.

Printing
Print with the inside face of each part on the print bed. This should work perfectly for any printer.
Try using high infill - 75% or above when printing.

Any ideas let me know. Enjoy!

title: 2020 Threaded Rod Brace
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I really liked butchja's 2020 frame brace, but I wanted to use threaded rods readily available at my local hardware stores. So instead of just modified his file to accept 3/8" threaded rods, I designed a openscad file to try to replicate the original design as best as possible.

The included stl file is for the 3/8" threaded rod at a 45 degree angle.

About the OpenSCAD file:

  • The openscad file is a bit rough, a few hardcoded numbers inside the main rendering function, but it works.
  • The nut inset needs to be adjusted (nut don't go that far down.)
  • Only certain degrees is going to work in the openscad file, I have no checks in place for out of bound angles.
  • I don't know how to do rounded edges in openscad, but that shouldn't be a problem.

title: Mirror and Laser Holders for Science Olympiad

description.text:
My daughter wanted some mirrors and a laser to practice with for the Science Olympiad optics event. I printed 5 mirror holders and 1 laser holder in ABS for that purpose. You could probably adapt these to a number of optics purposes.

For the mirrors, I ordered these 50mm x 50 mm mirrors (https://www.edmundoptics.com/optics/optical-mirrors/flat-mirrors/50.8-x-50.8mm-4-6lambda-mirror/), which said they were first surface mirrors, but they were not. That is probably OK for SciOly practice. We affixed the mirrors to the mounts with double stick tape, though there is a bottom lip for the mirror to rest on. Since ABS can curl a little, the lip may or may not hold the mirror square to the surface it rests on (sigh).

The laser was a generic laser pointer we bought from Office Depot. The laser barrel was about 14mm diameter, with an on light and on button that required a 0.5 mm clearance. I used this to make a sort of "switch" for the laser. The hole for the laser pointer looks more like a keyway, with a small 1mm or so notch at the bottom. When installing the laser pointer, orient the switch and on light so they can go through the notch. Push the on light through, but leave the laser pointer button in the notch. This is the laser "off" state. When you want to turn it on, just rotate the laser so the switch comes out of the notch, and then the mount with hold it down in the "on" state. You will probably need to print with support, and clean up the hole/keyway with a set of files to get the fit to work well. You'll probably need to modify the part for whatever laser pointer you have.

I have included the CAD files in the FreeCAD format. I know that is maybe not standard, but it is FOSS and works on a lot of platforms.

author: kovo

description.text:
This is a Work in progess!!! I only uploaded the stl, because thingiverse made me so i could publish. I wanted to publish to let people know there is a part in the works for my braces.!!

This is a Work in progress!!! for an adapter to the braces on my cr10 Mini. This is designed for those without a lather or a means to thread into the aluminum rod. suppose you could use 13mm dowel rod if such thing exists with this now.

So this is made so you can drop a 1/4 - 28 nut, or 6mm nut down into it, then thread your spherical rod end onto it to pull the nut up against its seating position.

The 13mm rod end goes into the other end just enough for you to cross drill a 3mm hole through and attach with a 3mm x 20 pan head screw/bolt and nut. this keeps the adapter from spinning on the rod.

I just realized that this will only work if you need to pull your Gantry into square but not push it. After I test print, I will make a spacer that you drop in that goes up against the Nut and the 13mm rod thus sandwiching it all together. Then you can mark where your hole for the rode goes.

title: 1/2" PVC Rotating Hinge (1 piece print, rotates 180 degrees)

description.text:
This is my very first attempt at a designing something for 3D printing.

I wanted to build a collapsible frame to enclose my printer for printing ABS. This is 1 hinge which I thought could be used for the horizontal sections of 1/2" Sched 40 PVC pipe. Another hinge is needed, however, for where the corners meet the vertical supports, which I have not yet designed. If anyone has any ideas please share!

As such, I have tested only that the PVC pipe fits and the hinge rotates.

Printer:

Creality CR-10S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

.16

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Adjust the bed orientation so that one of the sides lay flat on the bed as shown in the picture.

I printed without supports, another picture shows the messy bridging as a result. It printed for me without supports, and worked after applying slight pressure to break the light bonding.

Tolerances

After printing, apply pressure to open or close the hinge. It took relatively little pressure from me to snap the weak bond-points that formed during the print process.

It took me several prints with adjusting the slicer settings and the tolerances in the design. This design finally worked for me, though printer tolerances may vary and require fine tuning on your part.

title: Flush Wall-Mount for Raspberry Pi Touchscreen

description.text:
The Raspberry Pi 7" Touchscreen is an amazing, affordable piece of tech. I decided I wanted to mount one to my wall to use for home automation. But none of the DIY mounts I found online dealt with the problem of how to flush mount it with no exposed wires. This project shows you how to do it using a 3-gang electrical box and a handful of 3D-printed parts.

The full project description is here on Instructables.com: https://www.instructables.com/id/Flush-Wall-Mounted-Raspberry-Pi-Touchscreen/

After some iteration, I arrived at an improved design which makes the faceplate stiffer, and brings the bezel closer to the wall. These are faceplate_v2 and bezel_v2. I recommend using the v2 parts instead of the original ones, but left the originals here since they're the ones pictures in the Instructable.

author: spocky

description.text:
This is an enclosure for a VR Headtracker from DaleyTech (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pGP1qxwR1Lc).
You need:
1 PingPong Ball
8 Ohm resistor
battery holder (2xAA)
Wires
Switch
LED (http://r.ebay.com/GLVlNe)
Printed case and lid

Put a switch into the case, solder the positive wire to it and connect it with the 8 Ohm resistor to your led. Then add ground and solder it to the led. Drill a hole into your ball matching the size of the LED. Glue the LED into the lid and the ball from above. Close the lid and you are done.

For software setup, watch the video on DaleyTechs Channel.

description.text:
This is a three-deck Ticket to Ride card holder partially inspired by some other designs but also designed to address a shortcoming that I saw with other designs; and that was, where to store the extra point cards during game play. To address this, I designed this card holder similar to other designs except using solid walls rather then just corner posts. This gave me the ability to add a vertical slot on each end with a thumb cut-out to easily store and retrieve the extra point cards. I created each end-slot to hold three cards, because I wasn’t sure if Europe, 1912, and other variants had additional point cards that would need to be stored.

Specs:
This holder is designed for the full-size 1910 cards, not the original mini cards and is intended to hold the draw pile, tickets, discard pile, and extra pint cards

Credits:
While this is not a direct remix of another design, it was inspired by several other designs that I saw here on Thingiverse.

General three-deck inspiration and “Ticket to Ride” text from HunterGreen (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:231748)

Adding decoration to the deck holder was inspired by celticht32 (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1447488)

For the train car decoration I used four of the cars designed by bobpony

comments.text: I tried this and it came out pretty well, but I'm having trouble mounting it.  The stock screws don't seem to be long enough to reach the inner (silver) steel tapped hole.  How did you manage to get yours to reach?
comments.author: Yoshi360

comments.text: Your power supply probably moved in when you took the screws out. You can do a couple things. 1. Try loosening the other 2 screws further down the side. 2. Screw 1 screw back in without the SD mount and it will pull the power supply in, then you can catch 1 screw through the SD mount, remove the screw you just put in to pull the PS back and rotate the sd mount up and put last screw in. And lastly unplug the box take the bottom panal off and hold the power supply untill you catch the screws. Should work fine. I've had mine in and out a dozen times. The screws are long enough.

title: Camera Mount for Diatone Grasshopper 160mm Frame

description.text:
This is a camera mount for Diatone Grasshopper 160mm frame. (https://www.banggood.com/Diatone-Grasshopper-160-G160-Carbon-Fiber-Quadcopter-Frame-Kit-w-BEC-Power-Distribution-Board-p-995924.html)

I wanted to mount my new Foxeer Predator Mini Camera (22mm wide) but the Grasshopper frame doesn't have enough clearance for the lens.

I originally created a canopy for the frame (See https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2748912 ). But I wanted to be able to use the stock top plate so that I can mount my battery on top. I also wanted to move the camera forward so that props won't be visible in FPV feed as well as in Runcan Split HD video. The result is this camera mount that you can install using front standoffs. (I use 5mm x 35mm standoffs).

Design objectives

  • Able to mount 22mm wide cameras (Foxeer Predator, Runcam Split, etc)
  • Move the location of the camera forward so that propellers won't be in view when using 4-inch propellers.
  • Able to adjust the tilt angle of the camera.
  • Have sufficient rigidity to protect the camera even in a frontal impact.

You can print without any support. I use Saint Smart TPU at 45% infill, 0.30mm layer height.

author: d300vs

description.text:
Use this tool to measure out 1,2,3 or 4 servings of spaghetti! (I made a smaller one (1,2 and 3) servings for smaller 3d printers 120mm.

The holes are 20mm, 28mm, 35mm and 40mm. This amounts to about 315 Sq mm per serving.

Fun math fact.
Whenever you double the diameter of a circle, the area quadruples. That's why the small hole (1 serving) is 20 mm and the large hole (4 servings) hole is 40mm!

The area of a circle = Pi * Radius Squared

Oh yea, remember Pi from school? 3.14
That only means that every circle is 3 times further around as it is across.
(It is just a constant ratio between any circle's circumference and diameter).
So... The small circle is 60 mm around and the largest one is 120mm around
(well, plus .14 but who's counting)
Who knew math and spaghetti were related!

Gene Chao (chair of the psychology department at Berea College) made a wonderful hardwood lathe-turned baby rattle for our new son...when it broke many years later we noted that the end of the rattle, when spun, would invert itself, the frictional torque from the table changes the angular momentum and pushes the heavy side to the top! title: Arcane Tower of Fil 'a 'Ment
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Gosh, over a year ago (!) I built this tower for my Frostgrave game. I never got around to posting the files.

Just a couple of notes --

1) The stairs are made from two files. Stairs -top and Stairs-other. The Stairs-other file has a small notch on the stairs where all the stairs fit together. I just used hot glue to attach the stairs to the center of the spool. I started at the top and then built downward.

2) The remix of Zoth -- the heart and base -- cover the hole in the top spool. I've included dutchmogul's "Zoth Heart" here, scaled up, for convenience only. I didn't do anything to it other than make it bigger. Thanks dutchmogul!

3) Print as many walls as you'd like. I've made 4 variants for you. One is in perfect shape -- punch some holes in it. :)

4) I've attached a Frostgrave scenario if I wrote, if you are interested. :)

Blog post here http://dmscraft.proboards.com/thread/4240/arcane-tower-fil-ment

Top of tower a remix of dutchmogul's Dark Heart of Zoth

Icons used throughout can be found here http://game-icons.net/

description.text:
I designed the Z-Block Dominion Enforcer to be used in our Wayfarer setting, I'm using him as a PC. However, if you need a spacer with a cybernetic arm, feel free to use him in whatever game you play.

I designed him to print on a SLA/DLP machine, but if you feel like having a crack at him on an FDM machine, good luck and let me know if it works!

I've included a lower res file as well.

We've set up a Patreon page for anyone who's interested in helping to fund us so we can keep making free and open sourced games like Pocket-Tactics, Discord, and others, not to mention the growing catalog of gaming miniatures that you can use for whatever you want!

Props to the mighty Dutchmogul for the base model!

Printed on a Wanhao D7, 35 microns.

Thanks for looking, happy gaming!

description.text:
Well, my 3d printer died so I can't print this model to test it out. I uploaded it here anyway. Maybe someone can print it and test it out for me. It requires 3/8" marbles. You can get them from some hobby stores in the floral dept.

I uploaded the whole model as well as the model cut in half for the top and bottom pieces. I added some feet to the top part to make it easier to print and adhere to the build plate. The bottom part I removed a couple of pieces that were floaters.

Hopefully the model should be able to print without supports.

Update 1: Hold off on printing this model for now. I got my printer working (mostly), and while printing the bottom half I had several standards that broke while printing. They are really just too small I think. I will work on making more of them (if not all of them) bigger like the three outer ones are so that they won't break. Also some of the longer diagonal ones seem like they might want to break too so I might add some more to keep them stronger too. So I think I still have some changes to make before calling this one done, folks. Sorry about that.

Update 2: I added a V2 of the model. I beefed up some of the standards and added some more to prevent breakage during printing. I haven't tried printing it yet so maybe someone might want to try and let me know how it goes. I'll try to print it this weekend to see how it goes. I will likely beef up some more of the standards so this is still a work in progress.

Update 3. I added a V3 of the model. Trying to get my printer to behave.

Update 4. I added a V4 of the model. The bottom part is currently printing. I already had a screw drop out of my printer while it was printing but it still might finish the print. I'll hopefully be able to test and show the bottom part tonight.

Update 5. I added V5 of the model. The previous version printed mostly and the marble ran for the most part OK. I have added some more support. For this new version, I'm trying on upping the Infill to 50% to get more of a grid inside the supports instead of hollow.

I'm using Tinkercad to design this and it pretty much is the max that Tinkercad can do. It takes a couple of hours for it to do a union of the entire model! I'm using meshmixer to split the model into top and bottom halves.

Update 6. Tried to beef up more of the model. I think the problem was my printer more than the model, but this should make it more robust at least.

title: Pi ZeroW exterior frame mount for Prusa MK3
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
For externally mounting the Raspberry Pi Zero W board to the rear of the Einsy enclosure of a Prusa i3 MK3 3D printer. Printed in PLA. This is a dimensional part so your printer must be setup to print accurately. Must remove four vent crossbars on the enclosure. You will need two 3mm x 8mm long phillips flat head screws and two 3mm hex nuts OR two #4-40 x 5/16" long phillips flat head screws and two #4-40 hex nuts. The nut carriers go inside behind the venting slots to hold the frame against the enclosure. The extension header just plugs into the backside of the Einsy board. You will need to remove the two end pins from the 16 pin Digikey connector header for it to plug into the 14 pin Einsy connector.

Print the cover smooth face down and the frame pegs facing upward. Print the nut holders with the hex nut cavity facing upward.

USE AT YOUR OWN RISK! DOUBLE CHECK ON THE PRUSA FORUM FOR ANY ELECTRICAL CONNECTION CHANGES BEFORE PLUGGING IN THE Pi ZERO.

Must purchase a pin extension (header connector) from Digikey https://www.digikey.com/products/en?mpart=ESQ-108-14-G-D&v=612

See this post for more information:
https://shop.prusa3d.com/forum/original-prusa-i3-mk3-f30/raspberry-pi-zero-external-mount-frame-t12551.html#p56488

Good luck, Enjoy!

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

150 to .200um layer

Notes:

Untested by designer

comments.text: With the use of the Digikey extended pin header block that plugs into the Einsy board, the Pi Zero needs only a standard type pin length of around .3 inches or 7mm.  Any longer and the Pi won't seat completely down into the frame.  If the pins are a bit shorter (say 1/4") then the extender pin block can be pulled out from the Einsy board to fully engage the Pi Zero pins.  The extender pin block pins are long enough to do this.

title: Basic Working 12 hole Ocarina (Remix) - Final Notes improved
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
EDIT: RobSoundTrack also made a fixed version of the Nimaid Ocarina -
his is available here - https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2755765
More EDITs: There's also a lower pitched version of V17 in the works: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2810366

V.6 SoundSample:https://youtu.be/6W6-l9NYwsU
V.10 SoundSample:https://youtu.be/FJdEca6Ykgg
V.17 SoundSample:https://youtu.be/Mz09SC4Y4mc

Version Notes

• V.1: High notes work, but are still airy.
•V.6: Angled mouthpiece and decent high notes. Sound sample included.
•V.10: Voicing wildly beaten to death. Ocarina is now more in tune to C5, but higher notes are still out of tune. Seems quieter. I might be mental.
•V.17: Voicing completely changed again: Tried to more or less recreate the shape on my clay ocarina. I have no idea if I like this one more or not. It is closer to being in tune.

Summary

The original model is amazing, but I had trouble getting the highest notes to play.
After a bit of research (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vFuYeW_OxEg&t=204s - I decided this was a #3 C Ocarina. May be wrong.), I found that the voicing needed some slight adjustments, so I did a quick and dirty modification to get it working.

Since then, I've kept trying repeatedly to rebuild the voicing to get the high notes to perfection. I'm still not there, but I think it's improved some.
The tuning is also much improved, but I think still a little off on the highest notes.

Originally, I had made the airway exit more narrow. The tighter airstream should assist the reverberation of the instrument.
The labium lip is now further away from the windway exit. This should strengthen the high notes, and make the lowest note harder to blow out with added wind pressure.

In every version I tried to leave the voicing rounded, as I like the softer sound a round airway creates compared to the sharp sound a rectangular one makes. Tried to make the ocarina a bit quiet, but if anything I think I made it louder.

Until I finally printed one in wood - for whatever reason the windway feels smaller (it resists breath a bit more than the regular plastic ones) and in turn appears to have gotten quieter. Perhaps the secret to a quieter instrument this whole time was simply to narrow the windway some more?

Printer Brand:

Robo 3D

Printer:

R1 ABS + PLA Model

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2 MM, Matter Control Medium Settings

Infill:

11%

Notes:

3 Perimeters/Shells.
1.8mm top solid layers.

Higher infill doesn't seem to affect the tone.

These were printed in PLA
The smooth one was sanded with 80 and then 400 grit sandpaper, then coated with 3 layers of Polycrylic Clear Satin wood finish. Was just curious how that would look, and honestly I think I rather like it.

XBox Racing Wheel stand for Thrustmaster Racing Wheel Ferrari 458. Likely can be adapted to other wheel types/brands.

Red parts were printed with Alloy910.

Black parts were printed with PETG.

All code provided in OpenSCAD.

Some notes / thoughts:

  • The feet are wrapped with a mouse pad cut to fit. Used double sided tape to wrap around foot and screwed on the fabric covers to fasten.
  • Code is what it is, not exactly enterprise quality but included for your enjoyment.
  • Should be easy to swap out aluminum tubes for cheaper stuff like broom handles by modifying OpenSCAD.
  • Although the threads in the front axis & peddle attachment are included in the STL's they don't print well enough to function. I drilled them with an M10 tap.
  • You can print the screws or use an M10. I found the printed screws worked for the peddle attachments, front axis & telescopic tube but did not work for the wheel attachment (Alloy910 broke when tightened).
  • I included supports in the STL where required as they are easier to remove than auto generated.
  • You'll need an old mousepad (or two), M10 tap, 1 M10 screw, 1 M10 nut, and aluminum tubes (Home Depot) for the build.
  • It will likely be more expensive to build this than buy something proper on Amazon.

Dye Parts, Heat Clean

PETG parts were not post processed.

Used heat gun to pseudo anneal Alloy 910 after printing (& remove support structures).

Dyed Alloy910 parts red using acid base dye.

Designed using OpenSCAD

Coded in OpenSCAD - not pretty code but it's attached FYI.

title: Airbrush Cleaning Pot
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is an airbrush cleaning pot with change-able airbrush receptacles. Originally designed for the Badger 350, I had recently upgraded it with a new receptacle to fit my Badger SOTAR. It should now be pretty much universal.

The 350 receptacle is oval shaped, the universal one is round.

It also features a cool 2 or 3 stage filter system.
The first filter sits on the bottom of the chamber under a little plastic frame.
A second layer filtration could be cotton balls (etc) placed on top of the little plastic frame. The 3rd layer is placed under the outside cap.

I had a problem with direct up-spray from the airbrush clogging up the filters. I created and glued a baffle underneath to minimize the issue. An uploaded photo shows the baffle on the underside of the base.

Einsy_Pi_Hole_OTG_V2.stl: Only change is the cutout for the mini-USB plug

Einsy-Pi_OTG-USB_Hub_Holder_V2.stl: Uses the same screw holes as the door and has a hole to access the the door screw. Hub fits a little loosely. Will not fall out and does not rattle.

author: murrayp0473

description.text:
Magnetic Feather Case

A case that sticks with you. Designed for Adafruit's Feather series.
Flexible enough to use from development to deployment.

Features

  • Optional compartment for a 350mAh LiPoly battery (with a zip-tie strain relief slot)

  • Slot for a rare earth badge magnet (source provided)

  • Support for Adafruit's stackable Feather wings

  • Cable management and routing slots

  • Upside down board support (battery version only)

Materials Required

Feather + Screws

  • 1x Adafruit Feather (ESP8266, Bluefruit, ESP32, Adalogger 32u4 were used during prototyping/building)

  • 2x M2.5 x 6mm socket head cap screws (source: Trimcraft Aviation RC)

Battery (optional)

  • 1x Lithium Ion Polymer Battery - 3.7v 350mAh 552035 - PKCell 552035, Adafruit. There are shipping restrictions on lithium polymer batteries, so a local source with the same model/dimensions might be more suitable.

Magnet

  • 1x Badge Magnet - Amazon 10-pack -- the one sold by Adafruit is tested as well

Printing

Print these parts:

  • 1x - Case (choose between the battery and non-battery version)

  • 1x - Cover (choose between the JST access and more enclosed version)

  • 1x - Magnet retainer

  • 1x - Reset button

  • 2x - M2.5 plastic spacers

Assembly

Battery

After printing all three parts, place the battery in first. The battery wiring can be routed through the front of the case, and looped up the side to the Feather's JST header. If desired, add a small zip tie (for a bit of strain relief) on the front of the case.

For the visually inclined, photos are provided below.

Badge magnet and retainer

The badge magnet goes into the case with the warning symbols facing up.

For magnets with a metal-only plate: Insert the magnet retainer with the 1st printed layer facing upward.

For magnets with a plastic backing: Flip the magnet retainer over so that the last printed layer faces upwards.

Press the retainer through the clips. The retainer should click in and press against the magnet. If there is space between the retainer and magnet, the retainer might need to be flipped over.

Feather PCB

Finally, add the Feather PCB into the case, ensuring the board seats into the case's rear notches fully. Carefully press the board down in front.

Attach a printed spacer to a screw by screwing it on.

Finally, attach the screw to the Feather PCB. The LEDs will be in close proximity to the screw heads, but should not interfere.

Reset Button

Attach the button to the lid. It requires a bit of force, so the best way may be to either shave off a bit of filament on the button with a file, or to press it in by tapping the cover onto the button.

This is the Sharp Or Flat Key to a toy piano. We bought it at a thrift store for $3 it needed two keys, the replacement works great.

This part has tabs and holes.
The center tab of the row of 5 is supposed to be exactly 9x3 mm in size. Same for the hole in this tab. The two tabs to the left and to the right are smaller and bigger with increments of 0.2mm. The holes to the left and to the right have increments of 0.1mm.
There are three extra tabs down on the build plate, all of them exactly 9x3 but in different orientations.

If you print two, try one of the 9x3mm tabs to fit in the holes. You will see if your printer generates holes too small or too big. If so, chances are that walls are also too thin or too fat.
In Cura the parameter to compensate for this is called 'horizontal expansion'. A negative value is needed, if holes are too small.

This test assumes that scaling is already correct. E.g. a 100mm rod is 100mm long. Plus minus a few tenths of a mm.

If you only print one, you can easily break away one of the three outer tabs, or cut away one end.

comments.text: The dimensions check out.  However there's a .5mm tolerance for FDM printers.  The 9mm tab fits slightly loosely in the 9.6mm slot and is snug in the 9.3mm slot.

title: VEX Robotics Match Controller and Raspberry Pi Case V3.0

description.text:
UDATE: V3.4 - 2-1-18

Fixed vesa mount hole tolerancing to all for a better clearance fit with hardware on pt 1
Fixed 75 mm vesa mount hardware head toleranceing with case frame on pt 1

UPDATE: V3.0 - 1-7-18

Fixed alignment tolerancing of part 2 with the pi I/O ports
Added support for 75 x 75mm vesa screen mount.
Added alignment blocks for easy case assembly
Improved mounting point hardware spacing
Improved SD Card access
Improved visibility on match controller status lights

NOTE: part 1 and 3 from version 2.0 are compatible with part 2 of version 3.0 however there will be some cosmetic misalignment, it is recommended to use only version 3.0 parts or only version 2.0 parts.

Raspberry pi 3 and vex robotics match controller mount to attach to the back of the vex field monitor stand or standard 100 x 100 mm vesa screen mount or 75 x 75 mm vesa screen mount.

Part 1 and 2 are the components that make up the case

Part 3 (optional) is just a field identification tag that could be customized per event, a few options are provided.

REQUIRED HARDWARE:

4x 8-32 x 7/8" socket head cap screws (attach case top and bottom shells)
2x 8-32 x 1/4" optional mounting hardware for part 3
4x 4-48 x 1/4" socket head cap screws (attach pi to case)
4x M4 x 0.7 x 8 mm socket head cap screws (attachment to vesa mount or field monitor bracket)
Standard 8-32" VEX screws can be used to assemble the case.

I believe a M4 socket head cap screw could replace the 8-32 machine screws, however I have not personally tried that.

ASSEMBLY:

part 2 should have 4 clearance holes for 8-32 screws
part 1 should have 4 interference fit holes for 8-32 screws to thread in

the 8-32" x 7/8" screws should slide though part 2 and through the vex match controller and thread into part 1 joining the top and bottom half's of the case together (see pictures)

description.text: just another tool caddy for the prusa tools

Hi!

Wife asked me for a clip/clamp/holder for the cord that charges her phone.

Made this small clamp that would fit multiple sizes of cord, from big fat earphone wires to little tiny headphones cords..

Basically, you put double sided tape on the side of the clamp, and stick it somewhere. To hold the cord, you just slide it in and pull it in the notches until the wire is snug. The USB cord it was made for fit perfectly in the middle spot..

It can VERY easily be made bigger or smaller, although you only need to enlage or shrink the x and y, the Z is fine at the current size (unless you have heavy, big cables I guess.

Please like it if you do, and comments are welcomed.

seb

PS: I made mine out of ABS because I was afraid PLA might be too brittle to handle the strain when pushing the wires in. It might work especially if it's a wire that does not get removed and put back in often. Let me know if you try.

PPS:I put in the .123d file, if you want to play with it. if you modify and post it, don't forget to credit me.

description.text:
A 1:100 scale concept model for a house in Western Australia. Positioned on a corner block, the house encloses a courtyard which becomes an additional room when the operable walls are open.

The project was modeled in Archicad, where it was broken into small enough parts to fit the build plate. This also allows for the client to take apart the model and get a better idea of the spaces. The parts were then cleaned with Netfabb and printed on the Makerbot Replicator.

There was minimal post production work required, with the addition of the lighting and battery back factored into the design before printing. Trees, vehicle and people models were from the local hobby shop.

title: Seb's NEW Anet almost circular fan nozzle

description.text:
**edit: guys, there is about 500 views, and over 100 downloads, but only 1 like. Don't be afraid to commit, it's just a simple sign of appreciation. It'll help the model get more exposure, and It makes me want to post more. Thanks!

Hi guys
I printed some of the Anet A8 fan nozzle, but didn’t like the ones I found (performance wise and because most also completely blocked the view of the object being printed), so I made my own.
To fix the viewing issue, I made this duct a 3/4 of a circle, so you can see your print from the left.
Regarding performance I made two things:
1- the round duct is tapered as it goes around, to maintain air pressure all around (as much as possible).
2- the air comes out through a bunch of tubes, that are angled down to prevent cooling the nozzle as much as possible and maximizing air directed at the hot plastic.

I made certain the total area of the exhaust ducts are about the same as the fan's exhaust, so there shouldn't be much back pressure. Some of the holes are smaller than others based on various iterations of the duct where some holes blew much more air than others.

It’s not perfect but it’s as good as I can get it right now.

Comments welcomed, and please like it if you do, and post your makes!

PS: this should be printed out of ABS or something, as PLA would warp (my original was in PLA, and I had all sorts of drooping issues with it). This is especially true since the exit ducts are quite close to the heating block and print nozzle. Also, it fits right into the fan, but I have had to use tape to make certain it doesn’t fall off.

PPS: you might have to watch your nozzle temp during the first few prints; I had to reduce my fan speed to about 50% (instead of 100% before) because the head would cool off too much with this duct.

PPPS I also uploaded the .123dx file if someone wants to modify it. Please make certain you give me some credit if you do that.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Notes:

Don't make it out of PLA, it'll soften from the nozzle's head and droop and catch on the printed part.
ABS works fine, I can't tell about the other materials.

NO support, but make certain there is at least 3 layers on top to make certain the top is closed off properly.

print_settings.Notes:: You will noticed that the holes are closed off.  This is a trick I learned that allows you to go from a larger hole to a smaller hole without using supports. The closed off section is only one layer thick so it will bridge the hole closed and start making the smaller hole on top of the bridge.  When print is done just chase the hole out with a drill bit.

title: Ender-4 Drag Chain Mounts for Hot End

description.text:
After seeing videos on Youtube of the Tronxy X5S with it's drag chain to the hot end I decided to try to design one

The frame mount I remixed a design from Trippindicular's X5S drag chain mounts. I believe the drag chain on the X5S is a 10 x 15 and since I had purchased a 10 x 20 drag chain had to redesign for the bigger chain. Original file is at address below

www.thingiverse.com/thing:2708865

The Trolley side is a completely original design. It slips down and fits between the spacers on the V Slot bearings and gets bolted to the trolley by bolt that holds the metal cover on the stock hot end (or in my case the third mount screw for the E3D mount). I am still in the process of rerouting the wires through the drag chain but figured I woudl get it posted.

Items you will need to assemble:
1) Drag Chain 10 x 20. Either purchase one or make one of the many available on Thingiverse.
2) 2 M5x8 SHCS (I actually use Panhead)
3) 2 M5 T-nuts
4) 4 M4x8 SHCS (again I used Panhead)
5) 4 M4 Nuts
6) A M3 Bolt about 4mm longer then your current bolt. For me this was a M3x16 but if you are still using the stock hotend I would guess a M3x12 should be good.

Edit:
The Drag Chain I used for this:
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01M1EUPC3/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o02_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

I haven't tried it but this is probably a good cable chain if you want to print one:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:611593

Printer:

Ender-4

No

No

0.2MM

15%

Notes:

You will noticed that the holes are closed off. This is a trick I learned that allows you to go from a larger hole to a smaller hole without using supports. The closed off section is only one layer thick so it will bridge the hole closed and start making the smaller hole on top of the bridge. When print is done just chase the hole out with a drill bit.

description.text:
This design was inspired by a request posted to the ATMakers.org page on Facebook for a way to make a capacitive stylus that could be used by people with limited finger control. When I asked the poster to describe the device further I was pointed to a commercial device available on Amazon called the Sixth Digit by Handizap Capacitive Touchscreen Finger Stylus Ring (https://www.amazon.com/Handizap-Capacitive-Touchscreen-Finger-Stylus/dp/B016X2GMZK). I read through the comments of customers who had purchased the product and found that there were some fundamental issues with the design:
• “Couldn't get them to stop rotating around my finger and you can't squeeze them to tight because it'll cut the circulation off in you pinky finger. Just the little bit I did use them I noticed that whatever the tip was made of it had already started to wear out pretty fast.”
• “Worthless. They spin around your finger. At 2 for $30 I laughed at myself at how I got ripped off. Looks like something you would get out of a gumball machine. Don't waste your money.”
• “Good idea but ring won't stay tight on finger”

I chose a design that would mount to both the user’s little finger and ring finger to prevent the rotation and found some high quality capacitive tips (https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B074XVH3JP/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o08_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1) for about $0.60 apiece. I experimented with using a simple bolt as a conductor from the tip to the user’s finger as well as special conductive PLA from ProtoPasta (https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01BDL4BY0/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o04_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1). Both solutions work well and cost about the same - $1.00 to $1.50 per stylus, which is a savings of about $12 over the commercial product.

The bolted stylus requires a 5 mm hex head bolt and two hex nuts. [The length of the bolt depends on the length of the desired stylus.] The conductive stylus requires only a single hex nut and the post can be arbitrarily long (or short).

For greater customization, the post of the stylus is a separate component as is each of the rings so each component can be printed out of a different filament and each ring can have a different diameter to better fit the user’s fingers. I have included simple sizing rings that can be printed and tried before selecting a particular sized final ring to slice and print. I provide STL files for the posts in a variety of lengths and STL for the rings in a variety of internal diameters from 10 mm to 30 mm.

Finally, I discovered that, by simply rotating the mounting point of certain ring types about 90 degrees, the same fundamental design could be used to attach the stylus to an individual’s foot. The larger diameter rings are particularly useful for that application.

You can get detailed information about the process for selecting components and assembling each stylus by visiting my web page (https://wp.me/P9evBA-25).

Note that everything you need for 3D printing is included in the ZIPX file. Ignore the STL files included on this page, They are just for illustration.

Enjoy!
Ken

Sixth Finger Stylus in action: https://youtu.be/vL_oSGm0IBw
Sixth Toe Stylus in action: https://youtu.be/TNfXjLh_Skw
A very long stylus made of conductive filament: https://youtu.be/esuzNmWnNLg

This is a USB powered LED street lamp. Very simple to assemble. A design inspired by the Golden Gate Bridge. To make this you will need these materials (see the diagram)
Note : All parts on the list, you can find on Ebay or Aliexpress.

  1. 2.1mm DC power jack (round) - female x 1

  2. 2.1mm DC power cable (USB Cable) x 1
    Note : You can just purchase USB Cable (male) and just connect it to LED

  3. Resistor 150~200 Ohm x 1
    Note : Connect the resistor bettwen LEDs and USB Cable

  4. LEDs (warm white is better) x 2

  5. 1.5ft cable (electrical wire) 1mm =< diameter
    Note : insulated copper wire is recommended (.5mm =< diameter)

  6. Glue gun

Have Fun and Good Luck!!
One more thing, the filament I used was glowing one. It glows at night!!!

Lost Treasures is a game where each player must hire a party of adventurers to retrieve the treasure from a forgotten dungeon. One player recruits his adventurers from the noble worthy races, the other from the dregs and evil denizens. Unfortunately, due to the rush to try to get to the treasure first, sometimes the parties are not as well equipped as they could be.

Adventure Party Recruitment is done via a simple card system, and the Dungeon board is created randomly, using room tiles. Combat, magic, and other actions are resolved by dice.

All Tiles have two parts as I have based the movement squares to be 20 mm in size. I have used a parquetry pattern for the wooden door spaces and a brick pattern for the metal door spaces.

20-feb-2018 upgrade
This upgrade is about replacing the gland nut for tube holder clips. See pictures
Experimenting with these clips I can to the understanding that the diameter of the hole where the clip is placed in is very important. Because not all Teflon tubes are the same size the diameter of this hole can be different. The Teflon tubing I have is between 3 – 4 mm. So for me it works best that to bore out the hole with a 6.5mm. But I recommend to begin with 6mm. If that is too tight, bore 6.5mm and so on.

print_settings.Notes:: An easy strength enhancement would be to double the infill percentage.

description.text:
Threatened with the specter of destruction by falling shoe rack, I envisioned tying the thing to the wall for stability. The rack sellers claim a capacity of ten's of pairs of shoes, so keeping them from tumbling down would certainly be a good idea. So, the design is a swinging arm that comes down to clip on the shelf rods, thereby keeping the shelves from tilting away from the wall.

The design is print-in-place, 0.5 mm clearance. I found it to break free pretty easily, no supports required.

If I were to print these again, I would shorten the width...the hinge pin length...and print with higher infill. Because of the print orientation, I don't think the width added much to stability and the ultimate strength is determined by the lamination strength of the layers of the hinge pin, especially where it attaches to the swing arm. Hopefully if you want to print and agree with the changes, the OpenSCAD file will make it easy for you.

A followup note: I installed the brackets and despite kid glove handling, the hinge pins on two of them snapped...real easily. So I drilled the whole pivot out 1/4" and hot melt glued a 1/4" dowel core in to rescue the parts. So there's your spoiler alert. I would modify the hinge pin/arm piece to have a hole to accept a rigid core like the dowel or a nail or similar.

Update: I have added a hole in the hinge pin to accept a glue-in-place 4d or 5d common nail (have to clip a quarter inch off the 5d) to give this part reinforcement from cracking along build layer lines. Consider boosting the infill from 15% to 20% or 30%, too.

I originally envisioned using 4, one each corner of the rack to the wall. However, I only have two in place...at the top corners...and it's working fine. Yes, I could give the bottom a good boot (ha ha ha) and the rack would likely move but I have 40 pair shelved and it doesn't seem to want to. I letting the Imelda Marcos come out in me (just the shoes, not the corrupt part).

This is a bike light mount replacement for the Planet Bike series headlights.

Printed in PLA on a Makergear M2. Designed in Autodesk 123D Design. The specs are taken from my wife's broken Planet Bike mount, and transferred to a bit beefier design of my own making.  
This mount is designed to use 6-32 X 1 1/2" or 2" machine screws and nuts. The head and bolt holes are a bit tight on purpose, as I wanted them to stay seated and not twist. The holes may be a bit small, but you can either modify them to suit or just drill them out a bit to fit.

description.text:
All credit goes to myyellowminicooper for an awesome gauge design.
I printed one cause they look cool, and then thought can I make it move?
This is the simplest way I could think of, and it works!
All you need is a SG90 micro servo and something to drive it.
So if you drill out the center of gauge face frame to 5mm to clear the stepper shaft.
Then drill the needle center out to 2mm for the stepper shaft screw. (or you could draw a new needle to suit, with spacer?)
Print the stepper block. Then make a spacer of 5mm diameter with a 2mm hole and adjust the length so that when you screw the needle to the stepper there is clearance and the needle is not clamping down on the frame.
Hook the stepper up to an Arduino or similar and you have a working gauge.
The down side is the servo is a little noisy, and it sticks out the back. I'm going to experiment with stretching the print in the Z axis and see what happens.

title: LCD Grid - Verctial Video Guide for DSLR (V1 for GH4)

description.text:
This is a grid cover for a DSLR LCD-screen to help out with cinematography for vertical videos. I made this to help me with my instagram videos after being recommended to try a vertical approach by a friend.

Check out his Instagram here!
www.instagram.com/henrikringner/

The model Is currently only in one version (for the Panasonic GH4), but there might be others some day in the future.
A key factor in this thingi is the felt. I made sure to leave 1 mm of extra space on all sides so that the felt would make it fit perfectly. Most importantly it also protects your LCD screen!!
I also left a extra "window" to the left of the center to make more of the settings visible.
I'm happy to answer any feedback or questions!

Printer:

Creality 3D cr-10

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

30 %

Notes:

I'm not that experienced and would recommend experimenting with your own settings :)
Please comment if you find some good ones to share with us!

Finish:

When the prints where done I sanded it down with some sandpaper. Before adding the the felt I put the handle in place so that the felt would cover the screw from the inside, protecting the LCD screen. After that I gently mounted the back piece, constantly testing the tightness around the LCD.

After tightening it the first time i can just slide it on and off, super smooth!

The handle and screws are spare parts I had at my disposal at the time, but i will try to take measurements of them and update the info if needed.

This is a modified version of the BCN3D Sigma spool holder.

For some filament brands 1kg spools I had issues with :

  • The spool having a bigger diameter, and touching the machine on the bottom
  • The spool being too large, meaning it won't fit on the original spool holder

This spool holder allow you to fit these larger or bigger 1kg spool, without having to use an external spool holder.
Designed in Fusion 360 based on the original spool holder.

Battery holder
I made yet another battery holder as a first project.

The Cell part support CR2032, CR 2026, CR 2016, AG12, AG5, AG4, AG3, CR 44 and 9v

For: Monoprice maker select V2, Wanhao duplicator i3 and other clones with the same spool holder.

I designed this to be a simple, yet effective solution to a spool holder that is too small to accommodate larger spools of filament.

The rounded geometry allows the spool to roll with low friction.

One of the best things about this spool holder is the easy installation. You simply slide it over the original spool holder and it locks in place. No hardware required!

The spool holder extension will hold spools with a width of up to 83mm.

I might make a modified longer version in the future, but as for now, this one handles every spool I've come across so far.

I hope you enjoy this mod as much as i do.

NOTE2: It requires messing with electronics. If you are unsure about what you are doing - don't do it. I take no responsibility whatsoever!

Install and setup electronics
  1. Find a good reliable power supply. Something like 12V 1A did the trick in my case.
  2. Solder the jacks to the DC-DC modules, and install everything into the box.
  3. Mount it on the wall.
  4. Use a multimeter to adjust current and voltage to fit the description on the stock power bricks.
  5. Connect the wiring to you gadgets and tripplecheck that everything is working

title: Battery enclosure with USB insert for Anker Astro E1

description.text:
This bracket holds the Anker Astro E1 'candy bar' size portable rechargeable battery (6700mAh), and includes an insert for a USB type A male connector for power output. The USB connector is aligned to plug right into the battery when inserted into the bracket. Great way to provide 5v power for a portable arduino project. I created this bracket during a recent build of an arduino nano powered LED sign. The battery powered the arduino and 50 APA102-C individually addressable LEDs for about 16 hours of continual use with constantly changing color/brightness (not full white).

There are two versions of the bracket included. One with four countersunk screw tabs if you are mounting it directly to a flat plane. The other version has two of those same tabs to mount to the base surface, and two holes in one of the sides of the case to mount to a perpendicular surface for a reduced footprint when using in a location with support on two sides. This second version is the one pictured. You'll see it has two circular holes opposite the countersunk screws for screwdriver access.

The bracket was designed to be as low profile as possible as it was initially made to be completely hidden underneath the front edge of the sign meaning it is almost entirely hidden and difficult to access/manipulate. For these reasons the bracket includes a circular channel and recess for a DIY eject button. I made this eject button from a small bolt, washer, spring and locknut (see photo for sizes). This button makes it easy to remove the battery by pusing it just far enough to disconnect it from the USB jack where it can be easily slid the rest of the way out with minimal effort. The recess inside the box is large enough for the lock nut to rest out of the way when the battery is inserted, and the outside channel has an edge for the spring to rest and compress against.

I wired the +5v and ground pins from the battery USB connector to the USB input on the nano, and wired a simple rocker on/off switch in-line on the +5v lead so the arduino isn't drawing power all the time.

https://youtu.be/gB1WeZFEpy4

description.text:
X-UAV Talon Parachute Hatch V1

Introduction

This is a simple servo-controlled parachute release mechanism for the X-UAV Talon. It requires one 9g-Servo and parts from the talon's (useless) side landing gear to assemble.
Since I haven't finished building my Talon yet, this is untested so far, so use at your own risk!
It easily fits a 4kg parachute like the one available on Banggood.

I've tested this release mechanism on my talon with wing extensions and it works very well (video coming later).

Also included is an optional file for a GoPro Hero 5-Mount in the parachute hatch that can be fixed with 2x10mm magnets (if you want to drop smaller stuff and film it :) )

Feel free to ask any questions!

Installation Instructions

Additional materials:

  • two 10mm carbon spars
  • screws for the servo
  • CA glue (for gluing parts to the carbon spars)
  • UHU POR for the rope guide parts

Click here for full build instructions!

Alfil creado por Azucena con Tinkercad

So, I'm a geek girl who lies to tinker with electronics, but I'm also a cheapskate, and my vision isn't the best. Add the fact that SMT soldering is a really hard without magnification, and I decided to buy one of those crappy 14$ USB microscopes on ebay, and it was kinda disappointing.
The lens mechanism and focal distance was pretty nice, but the sensor is only 640 by 480 and has really poor light characteristics. I also however have an old lifecam studio that picked up on sale a while back, and I never use it.

I looked around online to see if the lifecam had been converted to a microscope, and it has. There is a kit out there you can buy, but the lens cost $50!!! And its only fixed focal distance! Jeez, what a rip off. After taking apart the crappy microscope, I noticed that it would be possible to Frankenstein the two together and create the exact thing that is being sold, a fixed focal distance microscope that gives you plenty of room to get soldering tools under, and has a full HD picture with excellent response time!
