title: Prusa Multi Material Wall Mount and Filament Guide
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Spool wall mounting solution for Original Prusa i3 MK2 Multi Material Upgrade. The MMU design has the filament path coming into the extruders from below which is quite awkward. There are alternative extruder mounts that address this but I wanted to keep mine stock so I designed this solution.

It uses very cheap (about $3) curtain rod holders from IKEA to hold the spools on the wall and then adds a filament guide further down on the wall to take in the filament from above and feed it upward to the printer on a similar angle to the included holders (but higher).

The filament guides also add enough resistance to stop the filament unwinding back onto the spools but not so much as to create extrusion problems. While the original MMU spool holder includes PTFE segments as well it does not seem to be as effective at this.

You can of course take as much or as little of this Thing as you need. There are many possible mounting solutions this is simply one that has worked well for me.

BOM

  • 5 x IKEA BETYDLIG Curtain Rod Holder
  • 8 x M3x10mm Cap Head Screw
  • 8 x M3 Square Nut
  • 1 x 1m PTFE Tube
  • 4 x Wall Screws
  • 1 x 1m M8 Threaded Rod
  • 16 x M8 Nut
  • 16 x 608 Bearing

Printed Parts

  • 5 x Betydlig_rod_holder.stl
  • 8 x Spool_hub_608.stl
  • 1 x MMU_wall_bracket.stl
  • 4 x MMU_filament_guide.stl

Any suitable curtain rod holder would of course be ok to use but might require different printed parts to adapt. Note that the BETYDLIG should be mounted with the short part on the wall and the long part on sticking out for the spool. The plastic cover provided with the BETYDLIG needs to be cut down, there is a guide mark on the plastic for that.

When sourcing PTFE, if using sources such as Gearbest, Aliexpress or Bangood I would suggest ordering multiple sets from different sources as quality varies widely. Of course, if you want even more overkill than this Thing is already you could use Capricorn.

The included spool hubs are nothing special, just designed to fit the spools I am using (eSUN) without much overspill, there are many great alternatives on Thingiverse to choose from. Anything that sits on M8 rods should work with this Thing.

See below for printing and assembly instructions.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2 MMU

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

0.2mm should be perfectly fine for all parts however I would not push the quality any lower for the filament guides as the PTFE needs to fit snugly but without any pressure on the tube. Lower resolutions may negatively affect this.

If you want to get the look shown in the photos with the filament guides then print with 0 solid top and bottom layers and 6 perimeters with a honeycomb infill. Of course you can just print it normally, functionality is not affected.

Everything is designed to be printed without supports. The wall bracket includes surfaces over the counterbores for the M3 screw holes to allow them to print well without support.

After printing all of the parts I suggest laying everything out on the wall with a pencil to check the alignment and spacing before screwing anything down. The brackets for the spools should be equally spaced, in my case I put them 120mm apart for a total width of 480mm but if your spools are wide you might want more room.

The printed rod holders can simply be pressed onto the BETYDLIG bracket. They are double sided so that the central brackets can be shared by two spools, saving on brackets and removing the need to place screws too close together on the wall. How you screw the brackets to the wall will depend on whether it's drywall, concrete etc. Google is your friend.

Assemble the filament guide by inserting the PTFE tube into each guide and triming to length. To get a clean cut of the PTFE always cut it with a scrap of filament inserted to prevent compression. The sharper the knife the better. Next insert the M3 square nuts into the nut holes and insert the M3 screws through the back of the bracket to fix the guides to the bracket.

Mount the BETYDLIG brackets to the wall with the spacing you want then hold the assembled filament guide up to the wall and check the angles look good. In my case the guide was mounted about 375mm below the filament holders. Ensure the bracket is level then mark the wall through the holes and afix to the wall.

The spool hubs are pretty standard, just press the 608 bearings into each side, a spare M8 bolt, nut and washer can be used to easily push them in. Cut the M8 threaded rod to length to suit your mounting configuration (mine were 115mm), angle grider works well and fast if you have one, hacksaw in a pinch if you have the time to wait.

Use two M8 nuts to hold the spools on (a single nut will unwind during printing) and tighten them against each other. It only needs to be tight enough to eliminate play, do not overtighten or the spool will not spin. You may want to add washers depending on your exact bearing type. Recently I have been experimenting with this Quick Release Nut on one side to make changes faster.

Once setup filament should be mounted in reverse so it goes down along the wall into the guides and up into the printer. I'd recommend doing a few load and unload sequences to confirm everything runs smoothly.

description.text:
This is a small battery powered display console.
Main incredience:

  • 2,9 inch 296x128 E-Ink E-Paper Display Modul
  • ESP32 Lolin board
  • 3 Buttons
  • LiPo 3,7V

I am using this device to control some home automation features. It's controlled via the 3 buttons, which are used as soft keys. The ESP32 is normally in deep sleep mode and wakes up every minute to update the time, or if the right button is pressed. The communication is based on Bluetooth LE to a central, which provides the current time and different characteristics to control the home automation functions.
I have chosen BLE in order to consume less power. A 2000mAh battery should last 10 days for the clock update. The buttons are soldered at rows 2 and 4 and at columns B/G, K/P and T/Y.

BoM:

  • LOLIN32 V1.0.0-ESP32.
  • Waveshare 2,9 inch 296x128 E-Ink E-Paper Display Modul - B/W version to allow partial update.
  • LiPo with 2-pin JST-PH connector.
  • 2x8 cm PCB.
  • 3x 12x12mm PCB Push Button.
  • 3x Button Cap 12mm.
  • Dupont jumper wire - Optionally if you don't want to solder the buttons directly. For the display this should be shipped together with the display.
  • Screws and Nuts.

See also: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2789144

this is my model of the British light tank Mark VIC
scaled to 1/100 this is a very quick print about 1&3/4 hours in total at .015
Higher infill required for the tracks but low for turret and body.

2 turrets included , one with guns the other without (in case you have problems printing the guns) use filament or something similar for the guns.

title: Sonicmodell HD Wing Nose Hole Cover & DG Air Speed Sensor

description.text:
This has been printed and already glued on the noze of the HD wing.
It is used in order to improve the noze aerodynamics and minimize the air going to the Pixhawk FC. One of the noze plugs has a 4mm hole for a digital airspeed sensor and depending on your printer might need a 4mm drill to make it proper size for the sensor to go through.
On our Z-ultra T calibrated printer, i used 1.0 extrusion multiplier and the hole came out a proper tight fit. The sensor pipe will not need to be glued on.

I will upload some pictures as soon as its dry from the epoxy.

Support to install a webcam on the bed of an Anet A8.
By fixing a camera on the bed itself, it gives a fixed point of view relative to the printed object, so it looks like you're printing on a fixed plate where only the extruder moves along x, y, z.
This enables great timelapses!
Of course the bed is too hot to accommodate a printed support so the support is fixed on the lower rail, using the last two screws of the linear bushing holders, see picture.

Depending on your webcam model, you'll have to adapt the upper plate features to be able to mount it. The scad file is available.
Notes if you want to adapt this design: initially I had a much thinner support but then the support is quite flexible and it oscillates when the bed accelerates along Y axis.

Little test: https://youtu.be/NjxL16GNDdk

title: JT ER2 Paintball - Pump Handle Pins

description.text:
This is a replacement pin for the JT ER2 Paintball Pistol's pump handle retention pin. The stock pins are held in place by small o-rings that can be a pain to remove, and can crack and break. This replacement pin does not use an o-ring, but instead is designed to snap in place. This makes it both easier to remove and to install than the original pin.

Note: I suggest printing this on its side with supports and 100% infill.

title: Keyboard support
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This model is designed to keep a keyboard separated from the table, freeing the workspace to use a digitizer tablet, a joystick, a steering wheel or similar and to have the keyboard in a comfortable place, it is not practical to write because it trembles due to the The length of the arm and the padding used is quite strong, although it can be made more solid by increasing the fill or printing it in ABS if you want to write on it.
I designed it for the Logitech K330 keyboard, although I think it will adapt well to most keyboards, since it can be adapted to measurements between 15 and 18 cm wide thanks to the lower moving part, which fits the keyboard by means of a rubber that joins the 2 parts of the base forming a v. It is 2 cm high at the top and 1 cm at the bottom in the stops that hold the keyboard as you can see in the photos.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2-0.3mm

Infill:

35-80%

Notes:

For this model I used different fillings and layer heights to reduce the printing time.
I used 0.2mm layer height for nuts and bolts and 0.3mm for larger parts. As for the filling I used 80% for the 2 parts of the axis of rotation, 70% in the clamp, 60% in nuts and bolts and 35% in the rest of the pieces.
For the laminate I used the curing program adjusting the horizontal expansion parameter to -0.15 to facilitate the assembly of the pieces.
I have only used supports when printing on the 2 pieces of the base of the keyboard, although the last piece is possible to print it vertically and avoid the supports I chose put it horizontally and secure the adesion to the bed

A 40mm fan adapter I made to replace with the standard 40mm extruder fan.
I made this because I bought a more silent 40x40x20mm fan to replace the original loud one.
Since the new fan is thicker it can't just replace the original one, because one of the bolts of the part fan on the side of the carriage is in the way.
The lip at the top adds extra support and strength since there are no mounting points at the top.

The 4 mounting holes for the new fan are smaller than a standard M3 bolt because mine came with self-tapping screws.

For printing align the mounting flange with 4 holes on the heated bed and it should print, the lip is at 45° so it shouldn't be supported.

Note: For this model the bolts to attach it to the extruder are M3x40, the originals are M3x45.

This is a replacement knob for my Harbor Freight Bandsaw, which was broken on delivery.

1) Remove old broken knob from bolt.
2) Mill a 5/16" slot in a 20mm x 20mm square of 1/8" plate.
3) Print knob.
4) Slide plate into bolt head, insert into knob using a press.
5) Screw bolt back into bandsaw.

Here's a really cool Boeing 307 Stratoliner model. Boeing didn't make very many of these, and I think there is only one complete airframe left in the world. It was the worlds first airliner with a pressurized cabin. Model American Howard Hughes took delivery of the first one built, and all these years later, it survives in the form of a unique luxury yacht.

I found the original model here :

https://3dwarehouse.sketchup.com/model/11b1ef0f9fe3f65fe80771be8faac585/Boeing-307-Stratoliner

I then chopped it all up in an attempt to make it easily printable and whatnot. You'll need tools, creativity, and some model building skills to put this heap together!

title: OpenTibia Intraosseous Access Simulator
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Please like and share! This helps get this into the hands of the people who need it most.

OpenTibia is an open-source 3d printed training device for tibial IO access.

Demonstration Video: https://youtu.be/M2R9BBb9_cE

I created this based on the need for inexpensive and easily accessible training aid for medical communities in developing countries. I currently use this for training in Haiti.

Disclosure/Disclaimer: I have no affiliation with Ez IO, or its parent company Teleflex. I have received no compensation for creating this training device. My opinions of this simulation aid are based purely on personal experience as a critical care flight paramedic. Because the suggested materials have not been tested to prove accurate representation of bone or tissue density, this model could potentially cause damage to the IO insertion needle, driver, or prove inaccurate for correct simulation. Use of this device is at your own risk, and is not meant as a replacement for proper medical training. Please follow your own local policies, guidelines, and protocols.

Special thanks to Steph Piper (sjpiper145) for creating the original anatomic model!
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1030467

The model was designed to incorporate a 20ml syringe of 20.5 mm nominal diameter. Actual size and fit may vary depending on manufacturer, and accuracy of your printer and settings.

The model is printed in two parts:
The OpenTibia base is designed to hold the smaller OpenTibia replacement site of the proximal tibial plateau. This allows for easy and inexpensive model restoration after several access attempts.

The skin is simulated with “foam” medical tape. Appoximately 4-5 layers should be sufficient to simulate the dermal layers lying superficial to the tibia.

Please contact me with any feedback or suggestions! Tips and donations are greatly appreciate, but not required.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.15-0.2

Infill:

40% for base model, 70-90% for replacement site.

Notes:

Model testing was done using ABS, but PLA would probably function similarly.

remixed_from.author: migeorge
remixed_from.title: Dual Extruder Proximity Sensor Mount (SN04) (HE3D Ei3/Tevo Tarantula)

title: Dual Fang Duct plus SN04 Mount

description.text:
After getting my Tevo Tarantula and hearing everyone rave about the Dual Fang cooling duct, I decided I needed one. But at the same time, I was needing to move my SN04 prox sensor out of that horrendous spot on the back of the extruder so I could adjust it. I found 2 items I needed, but according to the Pauli exclusion, 2 objects cannot occupy the same space at the same time.

So, working with Bryceletarmo, I was able to get the original CAD file for the fan duct. I then used migeorge's design and redrew it in AutoCAD to fit what I needed. Merged the 2 items together, and here we go.

If it wasn't for Bryceletarmo and migeorge's work ahead of me, I am not sure I would have been able to pull this off. Thank you to the both of them.

The fan is a 40x40mm fan, as described by Bryceletarmo. The SN04 mount uses the same bolts and washers provided (at least they worked on mine). I suggest adding a washer on the back side of the printed mount, just to make sure the bolt head or nut doesn't pull through. Fan bolts use the same size as the electronics housing fan (in fact, same size fan). Just thread the bolts through the plastic. Usual warning, don't over tighten or you may strip the plastic out.

author: TimothyF

title: Ultimaker Rp 1/8" Bowden Push Fit Connector

description.text: Update: now tested, worked great as it was! Still untested design for mounting 1/8" pneumatic push fit connectors. The design is based on hugokernel's http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:177209 but was heavily modified (stripped down, some refined measurements and simplifications). I also modified the thread library, because I was unsure if the pitch was correctly calculated (may work without modification). I played around with hulls to achieve structural stiffness, hope you like it :) Update: introduced a correction factor to make the threading a perfect fit. So the 1/8" connection works now, last thing waiting for testing are the M3 hole distances, the diameters are also perfectly fitting.

Turns out great with 0.06mm layer height, probably also with 0.1. All you need to do is print and drill the bottom of the connector. But be careful: stop drilling as soon as you hit the rubber sealing. Otherwise you'll screw the locking mechanism.

comments.text:

author: tobiaskornmayer

description.text:
This system allows you to retrieve data as much as temperature, humidity, brightness and color spectrum (RGB rays).
All data are send by Sigfox communication every 10 minutes and are visible on a website.

The purpose of this article is to give you everything you need to reproduce the case and the printed circuit board.

https://www.hackster.io/plantsigfox-ei2i4/plantsigfox-weather-station-3d66be

You will find in .zip :

  • Gerber file for PCB used to connect every components.
  • "PlantSigfox_Case.stl" -> .stl file for monitoring case
  • "Solar_Battery_Case.stl" ->.stl file for power supply case

The monitoring case is used to protect every components used (Sigfox module, microcontroller, screen, brightness and RGB sensors) and to connect sensors (soil humidity, soil temperature and air humidity/temperature).

We also have a power supply case in order to use a solar panel in addition to sector power supply. This is connected to our system by two wires (USB and jack).

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

PRINTING TIME

Green case :
20 hours for the general case, 6 hours for the door.
The frame for brightness and screen: 45min

Power supply case :
6 hours for pink part + 6 hours for red part and 1h for yellow the frame.

If you want to know more about our project, components used, programs and website, you can find all details on our Hackster article :

https://www.hackster.io/plantsigfox-ei2i4/plantsigfox-weather-station-3d66be

This system was made as part of a Polytech Sorbonne project.

title: Phone stand with reversible charge cable

description.text:
A phone stand for both Android and iPhone (Tablets should work, but might be a bit wobbly!), that has an integrated slot under the phone for a charging cable.

You can reverse the positioning of the cable so that it is the correct orientation for your device (Android micro USB users).

The hole for the cable is a little larger than a typical cable. I have tried a few and it fitted, but if yours does not fit you could either sand/file down the inside, edit the attached SolidWorks model for your specific cable, or use something like a soldering iron to slightly (and carefully!) enlarge the hole.

Using loops and recursion to create cool graphics from only using a few objects (square and circle used to create a snowflake pattern). The same functions are used but different parameters creates the different patterns.

remixed_from.title: MPCNC Bosch Quick Release & Vacuum Mount

title: MPCNC Tangential Knife Quick Mount Remix

description.text:
I liked this idea, but wanted to change the mount to fit in my Bosch Quick Mount Release (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2131782). After a few revisions, this is what I came up with. It will probably not be until March before I can actually test it, but everything fits together. If you want to use this with another mounting system, the only part you will probably need to change is the Lip mount.

You can use 4 - metal LM8UU Linear bearings or 4 - drylin Igus RJ4JP-01-08 bearings. Before printing all the parts, I would suggest printing TN_QM_TestPrint_15_2OD_24_2Ht_Rev18.stl 1st. I am using the drylin Igus RJ4JP-01-08 bearings and the cavity they are pressed in needs to be just right otherwise they do not give a slip fit on the M8 rod. If you are using the metal bearings the fit is not as critical. If this test print is not a good fit, in the TN_QM_HalfMounts_Rev18.scad file adjust these 2 variables until you get the fit you want:
Bear_OD = 15.2;
Bear_Len = 24.2;

If you change those variables, you will need to regenerate the STL files TN_QM_MiddleHalf_Rev18.stl & TN_QM_LipMount_Rev18.stl.

I made my own plastic coupling as it has more grab depth for the shafts than the metal coupler I have.

If you do not need to make any adjustments the STL files to print are:

1 - TN_QM_MotorMount_Rev18.stl
1 - TN_QM_LipMount_Rev18.stl
2 - TN_QM_MiddleHalf_Rev18.stl
1 - ShaftCoupler_M5x16mm_M8x20mm_38Ht_rev8.stl
2 - BottomSpringWasher_Rev3.stl

1 - MPCNC_TN_8mmRodBlade_Holder_Only_Rev32.stl (sized for Stanley Box cutter blades)
The blade holder variations that I am working on can be found: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2661474

The STL files spring_14_3ODx25_4Lx1_4mm.stl & BoschMount_Rev36.stl are only used for reference in the openscad file.

Hardware you will need is:
4 - M3x50mm Screws to hold parts together
4 - M3x8mm screws to mount nema17 motor
2 - M3x16mm screws to tighten M8 rods to sides of Motor Mount
2 or 3 M3x14mm screws for Coupling connection(M3x12mm might work)
2 - M8x75mm length smooth rod for side rods (80mm would also work)
1 - M8x120mm length smooth rod for Center rod
1 - Spring (I am using this one which I purchased from local ACE store https://www.primeline.net/sp-9728-)

For further info on utilizing this, see the original design: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2624654

There is also a thread discussing this design located here: https://www.v1engineering.com/forum/topic/tangential-cutter-in-development/

I added quite a few photos showing the assembly of this. If something is not clear, just leave a comment.

For infill, I used 40% on the Lip mount, 70% on the middle halves & 20% on everything else.

title: Rounded cube module - faster than minkowski!

The sample file contains a 10x10x10 cube, 1mm rounding radius, 32 facets.

This thing is a foldable clothes line toy for 18" dolls. Actually, it is probably sturdy enough to work as a real collapsible clothesline if one would simply use longer sticks.

You need to make some of the thing parts out of wood. Here's a list of what you need:

Base.
For the base, I didn't bother drawing anything up. I simply cut an 8" square out of 3/4" plywood and drilled a 1/2" hole in the center. I would probably not print this because it needs to be quite heavy to prevent the whole thing from tipping over.

Post:
this is an 18" piece of 1/2" wooden dowel.

Ribs and Stretchers:
These are made of 3/8" wooden dowel. The dimensions for these are noted in the PDF, which you can find with the rest of the thing files.

Pins:
I used a heavy trimer line for the pins. A piece of thin wooden dowel would probably work as well. The holes are printed 1/8 but I drilled mine out to accommodate the heavy trimmer line. The line I used was a Stihl 0.13" nylon.

Line.
I used a piece of cord that I had left over from a window blind kit. Nearly anything would work, provided it is strong enough. Most yarn is probably too weak. I installed the line in one piece, threading it through the inner holes first, then running it through the outer holes. This eliminates the step of having to adjust the length of each line (since there is only one line). I superglued the ends of the line to keep them from fraying.

Assembly:
Please view the video before gluing the ribs to the hinges. Also see the video for how to assemble the whole thing. It is probably wise to pin everything up before you glue anything.

Obviously, you can change the length of the ribs and the pole, as mentioned earlier.

I used super glue to permanently set all the pins and the hinges.

title: Audi A4 B6 Heater hose quick connector PLUG

description.text:
The quick connector between the Audi A4 B6 often cracks and gives you a slow coolant leak which most, top off to compensate since its not that bigger deal. However, these connectors often snap severing the connection between the heater hose and the coolant flange. This plug will squeeze into the broken connector from the flange side containing your coolant until you receive the replacement parts in the mail. Its tapered a few percent to give a tight fit. To give the printed part the strength to actually plug the connector you will need to anneal the print, 70C / 170f ( in the oven for an hour, then let cool with the oven without removing) Quite often there will be shrinkage from the annealing process, so you will probably have to scale the print 105% to allow for the shrinkage. When you plug the connector you can insulate the print by using a 20mm washer cut out from an old inner tube, and a similar silver foil washer placed between the print and the flange.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/hXmycT0sLu5

description.text:
I've been searching alot for some good fan ducts for my printer, but none of them really fit, or were to my liking. So I decided to create my own, which was perfect!

It is designed for the type of printer with that metal mounting carriage under the extruder with 2 holes 24mm apart of eachother

The air distribution was better than I ever expected, it is exactly how I wanted it to be.

It is designed with 0.3mm tolerances

There are two fan ducts, one with the round holes for the nuts and one with the geometric holes for the nuts, I designed the one with the round holes first, but then I realized it was really dumb because the nuts would just twist freely

Creating the mount

Creating the mount was the hardest part, I had to figure out how to mount it and let it still be strong. I found out that the left screw of the metal mounting bar on the printer was almost exactly in line with the extruder, so I figured I could put one screw in the middle of the fanduct and that was it, but It would be able to rotate like that. So the solution I found was to create a little bar with a groove so it wouldn't twist. Which is waaay stronger than I ever expected.

I designed it using OnShape, a free cloud software I really like.

You need:

5 x 15.5mm long M3 screws
1 x 11.5mm long M3 screw

optionally (recommended):
4 x M3 nuts (5.4mm on it's least thickest side)

I think you could all figure this out yourself but it's always nice to know!

1. Use the 11.5mm long screw to mount the slider bar to the right side of metal mounting carriage of your printer (put the screw in the in the hole with the little notch on both sides)

  2. Mount the fan duct on the mounting/slider bar and put a 15.5mm screw trough the middle hole on the inside of the fan duct, trough the other mounting/slider bar and tighten it down.
    The fan duct should now sit tightly mounted to the metal extruder carriage.

  3. Put the fan on with the remaining 15.5mm screws and use the optional nuts on the other side to tighten it down.

If you want to see any changes, leave it in the comments, I'll try to work on it!

Also i made it available so you can edit and customize the part the way you want yourself with OnShape. Don't quote me on my messy workspace, but it works ;)

When you edit the part, Please upload your final design to the remix tab, I love to see the customizations you guys make to it.

Use this link to edit the part:
https://cad.onshape.com/documents/ed6f8deb330a087d14d90108/w/5963aef8b5237733500e545c/e/1250eb22639944c92963d76f

title: Anet A8 Laser Holder for KKmoon 1000mW

description.text:
This is a holder I made for the KKmoon 1000mW 405nm Blue-violet Light Laser Head to be mounted on the Anet A8 between the extruder fan and the extruder motor as shown in the picture above. By design this holder provides a easy way to mount and unmount the laser head to keep a constant offset between each engraving/incision you make. The measured offset on my printer was:

X: +18 mm
Y: -1.4 mm

In order to mount this holder you will need longer m3 screws than the ones you will normally have on your Anet A8. I suggest going no shorter than 70mm.

remixed_from.author: PIEaters
remixed_from.title: MiSUMi Linear Slide Parts for FTC Robotics

title: REV Linear Slide 1" Under-slide Support Rail

description.text: This part is a 150mm long under-slide rail bearing for the REV 1" Linear Slide. Our team (11904) modified the part listed as a remix to fit our slide and elongated it to fit our needs.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1 or 0.27

Infill:

40%

Notes:

Reasons for resolution and infill:
Print at either 0.1 or 0.27 for optimal qualities, ALWAYS use 40% infill or higher so it can support the weight of the linear slide, make sure you do not forget to print with LINEAR supports, otherwise on most printers (with abs) the rail part will sag heavily.

Information about or slide conversion:
If for some reason you need it, the scale ratio between the 15mm REV slide this is based on and the 1" REV slide our team uses is 1.69:1 or 169% larger

Step 1

Pull the supports from under the rail.

Step 2

Sand every side very well, the under part of the rail can be sanded easily with a nail file.

How the part was made

The part is based off of a well made part (link: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1916338) that doesn't have a precise length. In order for the part to work well with the REV 1" slide it has to be a little bit longer and preferably a specific measurement. Make sure you print it with an infill of 40% or greater if it will be supporting excess weight

title: Belt tensioner pulley for large bed (Tarantula)

description.text:
Why I've remixed it

Because I've got a large bed, and I was loosing 3cm of printable zone.
The blTouch was not able to probe entirely the bed.

Also, I was lazy to buy extra screws...
And the belt tensioner is less high than the original, allowing a lower bed.

What you need

Nothing, except 2 M4x40 screws and nuts.
Normally you've got extra M4x34 nuts with the tarantula kit.
So do the change with M4x40 screws of idlers.

Also you save 2 M4 T-nuts. ( Enjoy )

How to install

There is only 3 parts. Go ahead on your own !

If you have some issue or question, tell me in the comment section.
Please put some photos if you've made it. :)

author: lorin2015

print_settings.Notes:: Sliced with Prusa Control software

description.text:
Front camera mount and VTX / Receiver bracket to make a Rakonheli 66 brushless whoop low profile. The parts for this build are very specific, I can't guarantee compatibility with any other part combination. I have extra screws listed in the parts list, I would recommend these so you have enough parts even if you lose a few (they are extremely small).

Camera Mount
The camera is mounted at a fixed 20 degree angle and is mounted as far back and as high as possible, however there is still a small angle where the bottom of the camera can strike in a crash. There are tabs on the side of the mount that hold the camera level and prevent it from rotating. The lens must be removed from the camera before inserting the housing into the mount, if the mount is too tight I find it works well to insert it from the opposite side and rotate it a few times to loosen everything up. a dab of super glue or hot glue can be added if needed. The mount is attached to the frame where the prop guard is screwed to the carbon fiber frame. these are 3mm long screws and need to be replaced with 4mm long screws for maximum strength. (Extra Screw kit recommended for this reason)

VTX / Receiver bracket
I measured the parts I had on hand and designed based on those, because circuit boards are not exact from batch to batch some adjusting may be need (a file works well to clean up circuit board edges). I used a bit of super glue to tack down the circuit boards after they were assembled into the bracket. The bracket leaves the top of the ATX03 exposed to crashes, I will update the design to add some protection later. For an even cleaner build, I removed the wires off the ATX03, removed the protective coating off the wires and then re-soldered them to the bottom side of the board. I now have no exposed wires on the top of the quad. As a bonus because the FC and ESC mount is flexible when you squeeze the boards together you can trigger the receiver bind switch so the quad doesn't need to be disassembled. Also the USB port is accessible in the rear without disassembly

Couple of tips

  1. setup a work area with a towel or something soft and large to work on, the screws disappear as soon as they are dropped.
  2. Liquid tape works well in areas where adding heat shrink isn't an option or where weight is a concern.
  3. Do a mock up of your electronics on the workbench and test everything out ahead of time.
  4. Check your mounting pads on the flight controller and Esc, a bunch of stuff coming out of china has the mounting pads of esc's connected to battery positive. when I built up the stack I smoked the ground wire between the FC and ESC because the mounting pads were connected through the mounting screws and they are opposite polarity. if you find the ESC is connected to battery positive I would use an ohm meter to verify isolation before adding power.
  5. Don't use the wires that come on the camera stock, the ATX03 has very nice silicone wires that are long enough to run all of the equipment (camera, receiver and VTX) if everything is planned out.
  6. Spend a lot of time on wire management, there is very little space to hide wires so making them as short as possible is a must.
  7. Tweezers, Blue-Tak and a good soldering station are worth the investment.
  8. The motor wires on the sunnysky motors have a coating and don't take solder very well, spend extra time tinning them to ensure they will solder cleanly to the ESC pads. also keep the wires a little longer then needed, they have a tendency to bread easily and the extra length makes repairs easier.

https://youtu.be/_lYm87Gh1Gs

Update 1/9/18
I am experiencing some brown outs on the 5V supply when I have all of the FPV gear running. I would hold off on ordering this exact parts list until I have the issue figured out. I will be testing a new flight controller in the next few days.
I also added a picture of the receiver on the bottom side of the bracket.

description.text:
Meet Oscard, the only credit card action figure! Stands 3.5"/9cm tall.

Simply print, cut from the frame and trim the sprues, then clip together.

The space on his or her chest can carry text or a logo if required.

Use the photo above to determine which parts are which.

Beware - contains small parts - keep away from young children!

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9paskeHrlwY

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Print with no brim or raft for best results. Only tested with PLA and PLA+.

Takes approximately 1 hour to print.
Trim the sprues with a craft knife or sharp scissors.

Designed in Sketchup.

Oscard is a FDM printer-friendly version of the existing original model on my Shapeways shop.

I challenged myself to come up with the most interesting thing that could be made inside the profile of a credit card. This was on the back of a friends creation, the credit card drinking game by 3DPrintNovesia and inspired by credit card chess by Innovo.

Seeing as I love action figures, why not an action figure in a credit card? And so Oscard was born!

author: mygadgetlife

print_settings.Notes:: When printing with ABS you HAVE TO to use the heated bed!

title: Anemone Button Tentacle (NodeMCU v2 Button Case)

description.text:
Anemone Button Tentacle is a 3D printable case for NodeMCU v2.

It is part of the open and free #anemoneCloud Platform, but it can be used completely standalone as well.

When used inside the Anemone Platform the Tentacle could be used as a DYI Open Hardware device which can be easily connected to cloud APIs, mobile app and/or other tentacles of open hardware devices. All this completely free of any charge. More documentation about how to use this Tentacle in the Anemone Ecosystem can be found at: Anemone Docs.

When used outside the Anemone Platform it can be used as a cute case for your NodeMCU v2

You will need the following to assemble Button Tentacle

  • 1x NodeMCU v2 CP2102 (costs 3 USD only!)
  • 1x USB-A to micro-USB cable

I am not the sole author of this thing or of the Anemone Project. Anemone Tentacle has been created as a team effort of our great team at Juicymo and our client. See more info about who is behind this here.

Tentacle Visualization can be found at YouTube

#anemoneCloud

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

ABS 0.35mm (first layer 0.15mm)

Infill:

20% Cubic

Notes:

The Anemone Tentacle 3D case is available either as .stl files of 5 individual components:

  • The Bottom Part (Anemone_Button_Tentacle_Bottom.stl)
  • The Case (Anemone_Button_Tentacle_Case.stl)
  • The Mechanism (Anemone_Button_Tentacle_Mechanism_1.stl and Anemone_Button_Tentacle_Mechanism_2.stl or both in Anemone_Button_Tentacle_Mechanism.stl)
  • The Top (Anemone_Button_Tentacle_Top.stl)

Or as a ready-to-print .stl file with all components (to be printed all at once):

  • Anemone_Button_Tentacle.stl

In addition to the .stl ready-to-print file you can download a exported gcode file for the Prusa i3 MK2S 3D Printer with ABS filament setting - ABS_ANEMONE_BUTTON.gcode. We have used this gcode file to print our version of Anemone Button Tentacle on Kanárek (Prusa i3 MK2S Original 3D Printer).

Recommended print settings

The Anemone Tentacle case is optimized to be printed in ABS (but we have tested printing with PLA too and it works well).

We have used the open source Prusa Slic3r for slicing the .stl files into .gcode. The Prusa Slic3r has few advantages compared to the original Slic3r (like better supports and more).

Anemone Tentacle case looks awesome even on low print settings - which looks nice with a semi-transparent filament.

Global settings

  • Filament: ABS 1.75mm
  • Extruder Temperature: 255°C
  • Heat-bed Temperature: 100°C
  • Layer height: 0.35mm
  • First layer height: 0.15mm
  • Perimeters: 1
  • Infill density: 20%
  • Infill pattern: Cubic
  • Skirt: 1
  • Brim: 4mm
  • Support: Yes

Tips and Tricks

  • When printing with ABS you HAVE TO to use the heated bed!

After printing the second part (The Case) needs to be cleaned of supports.

When done you can assemble the Anemone Button Tentacle case.

The Anemone IoT Platform Story

The original idea for Anemone was to create a simple Open Hardware device which would be able to send information to the cloud (or internet) and which will be very easy to use for others.

Over time, the idea expanded a little. And we have ended up creating not just the Open Hardware device itself (we call it a Tentacle) but 3D printable case, cloud web application and even mobile application for iOS and Android as well.

And now we in fact have quite a nice ecosystem. Not with many apps right now, but it is ready to use! And that is where we need your help ;)

With Anemone, you can create a cloud enabled IoT apps in a very easy way and get them hosted for free in the Anemone Cloud. Or you can just print the Tentacle Case and upload a picture of it to the I made it section. Our Anemone Button Tentacle case is the very first "bug button" 3D printed case for the NodeMCU v2.

And you can use it freely even completely outside the Anemone platform too.

So enjoy! ;)

I am not the sole author of this thing or of the Anemone Project. Anemone Tentacle has been created as a team effort of our great team at Juicymo and our client. See more info about who is behind this here.
CCSS
This lesson can be used as a semestral work for any subject featuring electronics, programming and 3D printing.

In this project you will learn how to assemble and program a working open hardware device with a cute 3D Printed case.

The Tentacle can be used as part of the open and free Anemone Platform, or completely standalone. The project plan is divided accordingly.

• Preparation - Put all required components together
  • 3D Print a Tentacle case
  • Assemble your Tentacle

• Understand how Anemone Platform works
  • Understand different types of Anemone Tentacles
  • Connect your Tentacle to the Anemone Cloud
  • Understand how the Flow and Flow Editor works

• Read the NodeMCU v2 on Arduino documentation
  • Program your NodeMCU v2 as you see fit ;)

The following components are needed for your Button Tentacle: 1x NodeMCU v2 CP2102
1x USB-A to micro-USB cable

• 3D Printing
  • Electronics
  • Programming
3D Printing Setup: 30min + 3D Printing: 3h + Programming: 30min = 4h

• You need to have all the required components
  • You should 3D print a case
  • You should assemble the case
    • And you are ready for connecting your Tentacle to Anemone Ecosystem.

Anemone Button Tentacle can be used in a tasks like "Creation of a cloud enabled Open Hardware Device". An example assessment for students could be:

Your task is to create a working Anemone Button Tentacle open hardware device. Your task is the following:

  1. 3D print a Tentacle case
  2. Assemble the Tentacle electronics (see the Materials Needed section)
  3. Program the device (a detailed instructions are available when you will create a new Tentacle in the Anemone Platform - you can sign in for free)
The student assessment is a success when:
  • Students were able to construct a working Anemone Button Tentacle device and they were able to communicate with a Anemone Cloud Flow.

    • Students should work in teams of two.

• The Anemone IoT Platform www.anemone.cloud
  • Anemone Platform Documentation docs.anemone.cloud
  • Anemone Example Flows
  • All supported Anemone Tentacles
  • The authors WebAPI Team & Juicymo

    • The "sister" Anemone Display Tentacle case

author: Maker_at_home

title: z-axis calibration tool for p3 steel prusa

description.text: This is a practical tool that I have invented to equalize the heights of both Z rods. place the tool like I did in the picture and get the upper x-axis rod under the tool. At this point, power off the printer or the motors. Then if the upper x-bar touches both sides of the tool, its OK. If not, turn the rods in order that the upper x-bar touches both sides of the tool.

Keep the symbol close, for your everyday prayer!

Feel free to edit the .svg file attached to make anything you want out of this, for example a keychain.

Nothing fancy, just some builders' plates from steam locomotives. They are all less than 110 mm x 110 mm, so most printers should be able to print them.

The companies and locomotives represented are:

  • Lima Locomotive Works: NKP #639, a 2-8-2 Mikado
  • Baldwin Locomotive Works: ATSF #3751, a 4-8-4 Northern
  • American Locomotive Company: UP #4006, a 4-8-8-4 Big Boy
